Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-29 15:03

@me Yea, that's fair. I'm definitely less confident in them since then. I still use them for a search engine and I do have their browser extension installed. I have for years, and it's literally the only thing outside of what's built into Vivaldi I have that's doing Ad/Tracker blocking. That might even be redundant because Vivaldi partnered with DDG for that tech.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-29 14:58

@fedops I wasn't deflected when I created an account on my work computer using Edge. I used a Chromium browser with the DDG extension already installed for the rest, but my wife did her's too, and I don't think she's got the extension or the browser. I THINK that might be just a thing for Firefox?? Maybe? Not sure.

@daniel

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-29 14:54

@VincentTunru I'm not sure how seriously they're taking the whole "need to have the extension" thing. Out of an abundance of "caution", I registered all the names for my immediate family, and in doing so used my work computer with the Edge browser for one of the registrations. It didn't have DDG installed, but it still worked for the registration. I honestly didn't pay much attention to that "requirement" during the process and it didn't complain. Sometimes I had it, sometimes not.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-29 02:38

@cy@mstdn.io Fair, especially with their recent kerfuffle with Microsoft and their browser. I guess I trust DDG more than I trust most internet companies, which isn't saying much.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-29 01:36

@cy@mstdn.io Well, it's not an extension. It's an address that you use that basically strips trackers and nasty stuff from the emails before it hits your actual address. So, basically a mail forward service with ad/tracker blocking. You can also generate random addresses to be used and discarded immediately after use without giving up your private information to sketchy individuals.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-28 23:23

@Santral Yea, I generated a random address for some software that wanted an email address to download it. Worked great, and the email I received was Mailchimp, and trackers were automatically removed. If that address leaks elsewhere, it's easy to destroy and never think about again.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-28 21:01

Just used the free email protection stuff from DDG for the first time today. Seemed pretty nice. Overall I've got a good first impression. Has anybody else signed up, and if so what are your impressions so far?

https://duckduckgo.com/email

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-20 19:07

@jinxd I'm using Vivaldi, which has the same feature, without the * part. Just type like a search engine, and it'll dig through your history and bookmarks and your search engine of choice. Of course, that's all customizable, so you can enable/disable those options if you want.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-20 19:02

@ruari Yea, I'm aware, but in cases it doesn't work it still works like just a plain link. I haven't done a comprehensive test of all browsers of course, but in Firefox it just takes me to the page and ignores the highlight part. @EpicCyndaquil

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-20 07:47

@kev There's a couple things that help out.

1. Tab grouping combined with accordion mode. Basically, folders for tabs where only the active (or last active) tab shows on the tab bar.

2. Window panel on the left. Basically a folder hierarchy of open tabs. Basically looks like bookmarks and much more readable than the smaller tab UI.

3. Quick Commands. I can just hit Ctrl-Space and type in part of a title or a command I want to run, and I can run it from there.

Makes lots-a-tabs a breeze.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-20 05:24

@Tay0 Very cool! The pairing process is super easy. It's basically the same process as you'd do on an Amazon or Google device. Just login to the portal and tell it to add a new device. Enter a code and set some basic preferences like where you are (for weather skills and things like that) and which default voice you'd prefer, and then you're in business. They're still not defaulting to Mimic3 yet, and unless you're on a Pi 4 you probably don't want to use it yet anyway.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-20 04:26

@Fil3 Yea, the release blog says that the links will work for "anyone using a Chromium-based browser", which unfortunately is pretty much everybody. Vivaldi probably supported it before in that it could probably use them. I think this is just where it added a super easy context menu for creating the links.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-19 23:15

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-18 15:51

@ikt Hm, I don't remember exactly. It's been a bit. April of last year sounds about right? It's really just accounts need approval from one of the moderation team before people can join. We started doing that because Fosstodon was getting a lot of accounts that were just bot/spam accounts. As long as people throw into the "Why do you want to join?" field something that sounds like they're human and they understand Fosstodon is for Free Software, they're good.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-17 17:24

@proactiveservices Unfortunately memories are short, and there's too much of "We won't make the same mistake next time!" in the corporate mentality. Maybe I'm just being pessimistic again, but I don't see the needle moving back in the direction of onsite IT for a while. If ever.

@RL_Dane

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-17 17:21

@RL_Dane I studied Computer Science in college and the goal was to be a programmer. I paid for my education doing IT work. I ended up sticking with IT because it was more fun but now I'm getting old and those 2 o'clock in the morning phone calls just don't motivate me as much as they used to. Most of the "programming" I've been doing is just scripting and process automation, so I'm not sure I could jump back in to real development if I wanted to. I wasn't terribly great at it in the first place.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-17 17:15

@birnim Janitor's closet?

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-17 17:09

@RL_Dane but I feel like it's always been something the business part of the companies I've worked for would rather not have to worry about. They've been itching to get the nerds out of their hair for as long as they've depended on them. They were stuck for a while, but now the ability to have a technical product without having to deal with the nerds is becoming more and more possible. We've invented stuff to make ourselves obsolete, and the suits are jumping at the chance. 2/2

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-17 17:07

@RL_Dane It's hard to say. I feel like there's been a pretty noticeable bell curve to it. Yea, things are more cutthroat and less humane than they used to be, but when I first started I worked in the field for ~7 years before I wasn't in a basement or a converted closet. One of my offices literally doubled as storage. The paint fumes were horrible and I was gone in a year because I just couldn't stand it. Motivations have definitely changed since then. Technology was a big thing for a while, 1/

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-17 16:44

@proactiveservices Heh, I had to look up what "second-order thinking" meant, but I think that's probably something I excel at. I've always just considered it a combination of pessimism and paranoia. "How is what I'm doing now going to bite me in the ass down the road?" I just do my best to be lazy in advance.

@RL_Dane

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-17 16:39

@proactiveservices Oh, I'm admittedly terrible at that kind of stuff. I think my wife's number is about the only one I currently know. I've lived in my current house for 3-4 years now and I still sometimes have to double check my address.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-17 16:25

@RL_Dane Yea, it's been a crazy couple decades. When I first started we had to install the networking stack into Windows 3.1 manually. My boss got hired because he was the only applicant out of over a dozen that had actually installed Windows 95 (it was pretty new in fairness). To support my clients I had to walk miles and miles a day to personally work on-site. These days I'm working in virtual environments hosted hundreds/thousands of miles away and I don't see anybody or move from my chair.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-17 16:19

@RL_Dane Me too, but I've been working from home almost 100% since 2020, and in virtually the entire time I've worked for this company I've had my desk phone forwarded to my cell phone. I've never wanted or needed to use it. We don't even have phones on our desks anymore since my company does that whole "hoteling" thing. If someone called me and I didn't have it forwarded, I don't even know how I'd answer it. I'd just get the voicemail in Outlook.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-16 17:07

@hund I've been expecting something like this for a while. Apple's "privacy" push is purely marketing in my estimation, and by pushing it they can push competitors out of this market. Once those competitors are pushed out for "privacy" reasons, Apple can step into the void and absorb the market for themselves. I'm sure they'll still be "super focused" on your privacy. No better way to keep competitors out of the running and the money flowing to Apple and Apple alone.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-13 03:19

@whoisrbkn It's possible in theory, but the way that Mastodon is currently implemented it's not something that we can do. I suppose we could technically go in and make direct modifications to the DB, but that would risk blowing up the whole instance. That's just not something we're willing to risk. Sorry. I hope you understand our perspective.

Ooo, installed #Mimic3 in my #WSL #Ubuntu, and configured my new #Mycroft instance to use it. Works beautifully. I wonder if I can get all this running on the #SteamDeck when it comes in. It's #Arch after all, so I don't see why it shouldn't work.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-11 20:02

Eventually I'll probably move over to Hitman 3 or Portal 2. The remaster of the original Final Fantasy is in there too. Still one of my favorite games all these years later, and the form factor would be perfect and the hardware not challenged. Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-10 17:03

Coworker: Client1 is saying they didn't receive our file.
Me: Hm, we'll I can see in the logs that the file was created, encrypted, and picked up by them from our SFTP server.
Coworker: So, why didn't they receive the file if they picked it up?
Me: ....
Me: ....
Me: (in my head and not out loud yet) HOW THE $%&@# should I know???
Me: You'd have to ask someone on their team what processes they have in place to handle those files.

Day 13 of the #100DaysToOffload

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-09 16:45

@indieishere I know! I know. My first instinct was, "I can hide this! She doesn't ever have to know!" Then my finger automatically clicked the button and my brain went, "YOU FOOL!! Now she knows!! NO ESCAPE!! NO ESCAPE!!"

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-09 16:39

@indieishere That's what I was thinking! I clicked on your profile and was all, "WTF??? HOW???"

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-09 15:40

@Tay0 It might be worth it to try Mycroft on a laptop or something with a Linux install. It'll install on a Raspberry Pi and all you need to do is throw some speakers and a mic at it and you'll have a working version. The desktop speaker is cool because everything comes enclosed, but it's not even close to the only way to run it. I have Mycroft running on my PinebookPro and 10+ year old ThinkPad. It does fine. Might be a good way to see if it's going to be useful to you before spending cash.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-08 21:25

@Tay0 Still thinking about it?

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-08 04:56

@Tay0 That being said, I've only scraped the surface with writing my own skills or integrating it with Home Assistant. There's so much more I COULD be doing that I don't. It's got direct GPIO access in the back and I haven't even touched that. I'm hoping now that my kids are getting a little older that I'll start to have more time to do hobby type stuff. Most of that went out the window when babies started showing up.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-08 04:54

@Tay0 I use mine quite a bit, but I don't do nearly the things with it I could. It's the only "smart speaker" I have in my computer room. I do the standard stuff with it. Timers, weather, general questions, reminders. One thing I do a lot of is getting words spelled for me. Embarrassingly enough, my spelling is sometimes so bad that spell check just throws up its hands and says, "I don't know what the hell that's supposed to be". Saying words out loud to Mycroft is sometimes my only solution.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-07 21:26

@Tay0 Well, I suspect there's a couple reasons it's not being picked up.

1. The proximity to the Mark 2 release.

2. Picture is stock, which is a red flag for me at least.

3. Price. They're asking for more than the Mark 1 sold for new. They originally sold for $150 from Mycroft and the early adopter versions of Mycroft sold for as little as $100. Even the extendable version only sold for $150.

Still, they're not wrong that those are extremely rare, and finding a Mycroft speaker that works?

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-07 17:43

@RL_Dane Yea, I didn't even realize it until yesterday.

@fedops

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-07 17:41

@Tay0 How much have you played with Mycroft before this? Flashing the SD card is no big deal. I do it fairly often just to have mine running as smoothly as possible. If they're being honest about the condition, it would probably be a fun purchase (assuming you've got the funds to cover it). I could even pull a leg screw out of mine and run it down to the hardware store to figure out the exact screw. Might even be published on their page since the thing is pretty much open source.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-07 17:35

@Tay0 Hard to say. I'm a little concerned with the leg screws and the missing firmware. That means this person has had the case open quite a bit. They say they'd never part with it, but the SD card isn't expensive so there's no reason it shouldn't be part of the sale if the device is in working condition. The Mark 2 is finally expected to ship their first batch next month, and they're they're actively taking orders for it. That's running $300. Still, a Mark 1 is really hard to find these days.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-07 09:40

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-07 06:23

@RL_Dane Dunno, I expected more TBH. I like to try these and watch the progression, and so far the best I've seen is Replika. That one is kind of creepy in that its express purpose is to replicate the person talking to it. It came about because the original developers friend died and they built a chat bot out of text messages to behave like their friend. So, you talk to Replika, and when you pass on, people who knew you can talk to your digital clone.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-05 15:23

@whoisrbkn I'm not sure actually. Mastodon is pretty good about letting you turn off some notifications and leaving others. If I left them all on, there'd be dozens and dozens. If I just left things like replies and mentions, there'd probably be a manageable amount, but because I'm on Fosstodon most of the day anyway having my phone nag at me during that time just isn't good for my mental health. I've been trying to cut back on notifications in general for that reason.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-04 23:36

@Tay0 My first (other than Basic of course) was Ada, and then I moved to C and then C++. I did a bunch of random ones in college that never really stuck, but those were the main ones. These days I'm more of a scripter than a programmer though.

@Wylsym

Mike Stone @mike 2022-08-04 17:47

@jinxd Languages all have their strengths and weaknesses. Those strengths and weaknesses make them better suited (or worse) for various tasks. Of course there's always going to be debate about that because "better" and "worse" are subjective measures. When it really gets broken down to the bare bones though, the only real difference between a "script" and compiled code is how the code is handled after it's been written, not something measurable in the code itself.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-27 19:41

@indieishere No clue. All the houses were technically in "Phoenix", but one was in Laveen and the other three have been in Ahwatukee. If you're not aware, those aren't actually "cities", just areas of Phoenix proper that are geographically sorta separate. The 3rd and 4th houses are actually in the same neighborhood. We liked the house we were renting but not who we were renting it from, so we got a different house with the same floorplan in the same neighborhood. Better yard though.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-27 18:14

@indieishere It's really dependent on where you are. We've lived in four different houses since we've been living here in Phoenix, and the first one we only found one dead one the entire time. The second one was basically like living in a horror movie. The third not much better. The forth (current) isn't even that far from the third and it's got significantly fewer creepy crawlies. Noticeably fewer.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-27 17:38

Found the first scorpion (bark) of the year in the house last night. Feel like that's late, but not complaining. I'd prefer they kept themselves outside.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-26 22:31

@whoisrbkn Out of curiosity, what was the account name you requested? I don't see any recent requests that look like they'd be from you.

@fosstodon @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-26 22:15

@whoisrbkn That doesn't sound familiar, so I doubt it was me that reviewed the request. If you put in another request with just the first bit of your profile from mastodon.social or a "I used to be <profile_name> on Fosstodon", you'll get accepted. Assuming you're still interested.

@fosstodon @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-26 22:04

@whoisrbkn A lot of importance is placed on the "Reasons for Joining" when you're asking for an account. If your request was denied it's probably because of that. Some people fill that out in detail, but if a vague answer is provided or something like "Talk with friends", the request is going to be rejected because that doesn't require Fosstodon specifically here in the Fed. Also, we probably didn't know who you were if that part wasn't filled in. You're welcome to do it again?

@fosstodon @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-21 00:22

@MrBuggles Heh, the first time they did it I didn't know it was corporate sponsored, so I was like, "Oh hey, a phishing link. Let's see what it does!" Delete." Now I'm a good little drone and I report it to get the pat on the head. If you report it when you're supposed to, you get white listed for a bit.

There's no way our HR group would give us deals on Netflix. We can't even get them to give us training on things that are relevant, let alone give us deals on watching Stranger Things.

@Tay0 @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-19 17:52

@kev Not surprising I suppose. Dig too deep there and you'll run into some ancient Roman colosseum or Celtic village. We don't have them much around here either, but the explanations are pretty weak. The prominent one is there's "hard soils" that make them more expensive, so builders don't want the expense (even though owners probably would save buckets of cash on AC). Considering how many in ground pools there are around this place, I'm not sure I buy it though.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-19 03:16

@ru@smallcamp.art There's a couple different reasons, depending on how big of a jerk you are. If you're a nice person, you'll tap the brakes just enough to turn the lights on but not enough to slow yourself down. This is just a heads up for the person behind you that they're getting too close. If you're not a nice person, you may want to hit the brakes hard enough for the person behind you to actually rear end you. This is a way for someone with a crappy car to get somebody else to pay for repairs.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-13 03:56

@adamsdesk@mastodon.technology They still do subscriptions for some things in the Toyota. There's the obvious like Internet and SiriusXM, but there's stuff like remote start and door lock too. Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-12 23:52

@DarkWraithLord@mastodon.social I can understand subscriptions where continued labor is required for the product. Software or news are good examples. Updates are required so even after a purchase is made more work is being done. Heated seats though? Big no there. It's whether they're on or off. Maybe a temperature adjustment. No one is playing Doom on their seat. This is a horrible idea. I fully agree. Buy something else.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-12 23:44

This is the kind of thing I worry about when it comes to our modern technology. BMW charging a monthly fee to use a feature in the car you've "purchased". #BMW doesn't need to do anything to make this work. You already have everything you need to have the feature. It's just you need to be paying the fee for BMW to LET you use a feature in your own car. The subscription economy is out of hand.

https://www.motor1.com/news/597376/bmw-heated-seats-subscription/

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-07 18:44

@RyuKurisu are single words, but the street address may contain spaces. This is just an example and not the exact situation, but something like that. I had to compress down extraneous spaces into one space and put pipes in as field separators so as not to confuse fields that may actually contain real spaces so it was more machine than human readable. There was a lot more to it than just the commands I've mentioned, and I'm not sure how much detail I can go into without violating my NDAs.

@joel

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-07 18:41

@RyuKurisu Well, it wasn't a book or anything. The file I was looking at was data, but the actual text formatting was a little sketchy. I wanted to pull out particular fields from that data, and the data was space delineated. I THINK the original intent was the file was supposed to be human readable, so it had large gaps in the fields, and some of the fields themselves contained spaces too. So like:

FirstName LastName This is my street address

Where the first name and last name 1/

@joel

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-07 17:26

@eludom Yea, I know, but I always forget the exact syntax for sed. I could go look it up and it's not hard, I'm just lazy because I remember the tr command.

tr -s '[:space:]' if you're curious. I'm not going to look up the sed equivalent for reasons mentioned above.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-07 17:14

@eludom Exactly my point. This is the kind of stuff I type in regularly on a day to day basis, but to someone now in my field it looks like a cat got loose on the keyboard.

Ironically, that sed was only one command in several strung together with pipes. The one immediately prior was tr (because I can never remember how to do something in sed and it's easy with tr). I rarely use awk though. Never perl. If I have to get so involved those two are necessary, I'll write something up in Python.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-07 17:04

@joel Well, nothing on it's own. I piped a file into it so it has input, but the sed command itself just replaces spaces in the input with pipes. So....

echo "My name is Mike"|sed -e 's/\ /\|/g'

The output would be My|name|is|Mike.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-07 16:49

Ever just take a step back and look at what you just typed in and think to yourself, "I have a really weird job." I used this command this morning:

sed -e 's/\ /\|/g'

I know exactly what this does and I mean to do it, but looking at that command it's no wonder so many people think computers are wires and black magic.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-06 17:54

I don't know how big the company is and if your specific presence will be noted, but if it's after hours of the standard day, just opt out because you have plans or just say something came up.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-06 17:51

@sheogorath I'm not sure I've ever seen AOSP referred to as "Android" and what comes on phones and tablets as specifically "Google Android". I've just seen the finished products that are distributed with devices referred to as Android and AOSP referred to as AOSP.

@JoeRess

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-06 17:49

@Suiseiseki As stated by Richard Stallman, "Android contains Linux, but not GNU; thus, Android and GNU/Linux are mostly different, because all they have in common is Linux."

I consider Android to be useful. Android is a Linux distro.

@wholesomedonut

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-05 22:28

@RyuKurisu I think @sil was more in my camp than not, but I've honestly lost track. I think most of the talking was between Wimpy and Hayden. Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-05 22:24

@lig Saying it's a GNU/Linux distribution adds another wrinkle to it as GNU doesn't need Linux to operate and Linux doesn't need GNU to operate. A Linux distro would still be a Linux distro without GNU.

@hund @JoeRess

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-05 22:21

@RyuKurisu Well, the amount of success Hurd has gotten doesn't change the fact that GNU and Linux are not inextricably tied. Both can operate without the other.

@jacob@mastodon.arch-linux.cz

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-05 21:12

@yojimbo That is what I'm talking about. Arbitrary and fully optional components don't determine what is and is not a Linux distro. As you said and I said in the post, Android and ChromeOS are absolutely Linux distros. The only thing that determines if it is or is not a Linux distro is if it includes Linux (the kernel) and it's distributed. The end. It can be as complicated or as simple as you want after that as long as those two things are present.

@JoeRess

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-05 20:58

@yojimbo Agreed, but the more complicated this becomes the more arbitrary the definition. How long before it's not a "real" Linux distro if it doesn't include Firefox for example. Literally any part of a Linux distro is optional except for one, and that's the kernel. If it doesn't have a Linux kernel, it's not a Linux distro. Full stop. Stacking other stuff on top of that basic requirement is a road that leads to ruin.

@JoeRess

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-05 20:35

@hund I agree because defining an operating by which kernel it's running becomes immediately problematic when that kernel can be swapped out with no noticeable change for the end user. That creates a situation where someone refers to the OS as Linux when Linux isn't included.

@JoeRess

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-05 20:28

@yojimbo And that's fair, but we can't referr to that userspace as Linux when it may not even include the Linux kernel just because it looks like what we're used to "Linux" looking like. BSD isn't Linux because it doesn't include Linux.

@JoeRess

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-05 20:06

@underlap Dunno. I'd need more specifics. I have my use case met with yt-dlp, but if there's a more graceful way to do it I'm open to suggestions.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-05 20:05

@pixelherodev I disagree. That interpretation of language inevitably leads to philosophical debates that have no real answer. Instead of a cut and dry definition of what a Linux distro is, the question becomes a variation on the ship of Theseus.

@JoeRess

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-05 20:02

@jacob@mastodon.arch-linux.cz Fair. Linux and GNU are not synonymous. Linux doesn't need GNU and GNU doesn't need Linux.

@JoeRess

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-05 18:35

@joel For the record, this worked perfectly. Exactly what I wanted. I'm also interested in the solution @sultmhoor posted since it doesn't require an additional tool and I can probably parse out the RSS with just a bash wrapper. I'm keeping his warning about the random breaks in mind though when considering a solution.

@Wivik

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-05 18:16

@dusnm Well, it needs to be a working OS, otherwise the Linux kernel would be a distribution in and of itself. A package manager is not a requirement in my book. I remember using Linux back in the 90s when there were only a handful of distros on the market, and you downloaded the code and compiled it yourself if you wanted something to run on it. Those were still distributions.

@JoeRess

@joel Can't let @kev have all the fun!

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-05 18:02

In the two latest episodes of Linux Downtime (49 and 50), @JoeRess and a collection of big names like Stuart Langridge, Martin Wimpress, and Hayden Barnes discussed what it means to be Linux distribution. I love these guys, but I think they've missed the obvious and they're massively overthinking this. I've written my rambling response here:

https://mikestone.me/what-is-a-linux-distribution

Mike Stone @mike 2022-07-02 01:30

@Iutech I just noticed that there was an open appeal to a warning issued to your account regarding this post. The warning was for a non-English post. I'm going to approve your appeal because I think there's a misunderstanding here. On Twitter replies to yourself are treated like normal replies. On Mastodon replies to yourself are treated as separate posts in a thread. They all appear in public timelines. That's only the case when you reply directly to yourself. It's just platform difference.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-30 19:54

A fun and slightly weird introductory video of #Mimic3 by #Mycroft. Watched it last night with my wife. Her reaction was, "WTF was that?" Not inappropriate, but still funny.

https://yewtu.be/watch?v=KWw9LKSfAq0

Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-30 16:17

@Corvus You can. There are several different ways to configure the wake word. You can use a predefined model, you can define a new wake word using phonemes and #PocketSphinx, or you can even train your own model using #Mycroft's Precise software. It's open source and provides the best accuracy. #Precise is based on a neural network that is trained on sound patterns rather than word patterns. It does take a lot more work though.

https://mycroft-ai.gitbook.io/docs/using-mycroft-ai/customizations/wake-word

Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-30 04:20

@phillipcouto I have heard of and I have used. I'm still relatively amateur compared to most, but it's a really cool system. I haven't hooked it to my #Mycroft systems yet, but I plan on it when the Mark2s show up.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-29 21:34

@pixelherodev I haven't tried this personally, so grain of salt here, but it's my understanding that the entire stack CAN run offline now. The #Selene part is still the biggest PITA as they don't have easy configuration to use it and it's setup is a pretty big pain. It's also not a turn key thing to switch #Mycroft installations from the default cloud version to the locally hosted version. #Mimic3 is by far the easiest to use. Despite all that, it is an option to run everything fully on prem.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-29 21:11

@bob Yea, they've been defaulting to Popey since the original ap voice for the Mycroft Mark 1. The new version sounds so much like him it's almost creepy.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-29 21:08

@appelgriebsch

Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-29 21:07

Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-29 21:06

#Mycroft's #Mimic3 is now live and ready for use. If you've got a project that requires TTS, it could be a very good option for you. It respects your privacy, runs fully offline, and it's open source. On top of all that, there's hundreds of voices to choose from and speaks dozens of languages.

https://mycroft.ai/blog/introducing-mimic-3/

Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-28 20:18

PSA Regarding Mastodon

Replying to yourself is not treated by #Mastodon as an actual reply. It's treated like a part of a thread, and shows up in all public timelines if that's how the permissions are configured. This is particularly relevant to individuals who reside here on #Fosstodon and conform to our English Only policy, but may reply to posts in languages other than English.

@benjaminhollon Depends on the configuration I suppose. In the past I've used a docked laptop basically the same as a desktop unit with an attached keyboard, mouse, and monitor. Worked fine. One of which was the observed anniversary of the first blood transfusion where a 15 year old kid was given sheep's blood, and Elizabeth Holmes was accused of fraud. Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-17 17:22

Listening to one of our C level execs talking about a demonstration she received of some new AI/ML technology being developed in house.

"We walked through some of their AI/ML innovations, and they're true innovations."

This struck me as one of our highest level executives subtly admitting that normally when they use the word "innovation", it's really not.

"Innovation" has become a word that's so overused that it's virtually meaningless in today's market.

Got up. Innovated. Back to bed.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-17 16:25

@wilw Well, there are extensions like MultiLogin that do something similar. Whether it's a 1:1, I'm not sure without knowing your use case.

@gamey

Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-17 05:23

@adamsdesk@mastodon.technology That's the actual content. Vivaldi allows assigning similar hotkeys to changing the zoom level of the actual UI of the browser as well without impacting the web content.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-17 04:31

@gamey Vivaldi is the KDE of web browsers. It's configurable in almost every way imaginable, so I can truly make it my own. If there's another browser in existence that is more configurable, I don't know about it. It also has features like synchronized Reading Lists, a unique history feature, web panels, private integrated translation, etc. There's just so many features. Heck, it can sync smart bulbs to the color theme of the webpage you're visiting. I don't use that, but I could.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-16 20:51

@gamey I don't love that it's got closed source components. I'd much prefer the whole thing was open. Despite that, I still think it's the best browser for my own personal needs.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-01 15:50

@mrak What that department chair is saying is that all that corporate speak about caring about employees and being a family is all made up to make you feel complacent and obligated, and they'll rip you off and even potentially dump you if you expect to be treated with even the most basic modicum of respect. You're a cog in their machine, and that's it. If they're expecting more from you than what they're paying you to do, then you're being taken advantage of. That's it.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-06-01 15:44

@Gina We have two Roombas, one for each floor of the house. They've worked great for us and they can be scheduled to automatically go when you're not home or sleeping if you're a heavy sleeper. They're not super thorough though, and you're still going to want to do a more hands on cleaning with the regular vacuum on occasion. Also, if you have kids or pets that leave out toys or.... other things... that can be a problem for the automated cleaning solutions.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-31 03:47

Just listened to Episode 178 of #LateNightLinux. They spent a little time during the show talking about things they love about Linux and FOSS. I think every one of them mentioned the community, and I have to agree. It's one of the things that I think makes #Fosstodon great is that it draws from an already amazing community. Thanks to everyone for making Fosstodon all that it is.

@JoeRess @felimwhiteley @degville @8none1

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-29 04:40

@dirty A few years back I decided to do my 10K steps every single day, and I've done it for the most part since with exceptions for sick time and times where it just wasn't possible like being stuck on a plane for the majority of the day. I DIDN'T do that while I was on vacation, and I still lost weight. It helps for sure because of how stationary I used to be, but whatever I was doing on vacation was still better for me.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-29 02:59

It sincerely makes me wonder just how bad for me my lifestyle is. Maybe not my "lifestyle". Maybe it's just my job. Being up and around and moving more of the day easily compensated for a disastrous diet. Just more movement is all it takes to be healthier than I usually am.

I just take pictures of stuff I think looks cool.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-28 04:27

@MurrayWindripper Thanks for the heads up. Yea, they're not uncommon in the Fed because smaller instances need to follow people to populate their timelines. Until they follow someone on the instance the posts from that instance don't show up in their federated timeline. To get their timelines moving, they use followbots to add a bunch of instances to their Federated timeline. They're annoying but usually harmless. It'll probably never post, but you can block it if you want it gone.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-28 04:20

What is the general thought on airplane seat reclining? I realize that this is a super first world problem, but after just getting off a 5+ hour flight it's on my mind. I'm a fairly decently sized guy. 6'1 and 250+. As soon as allowed, the slightly built young woman who was sitting in front of me reclined her seat all the way back, putting the back of her head about 6" from my face. She then spent most of the flight leaning forward to see the TV screen on the back of the seat in front of her.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-12 05:29

@enteka I've unsuspended your account, but please be aware that Mastodon and Twitter are not the same thing and they don't always behave the same way. When you imported your Twitter posts, you basically dumped all of them into the timelines of 20000+ people all at the same time. The posts may not have been intended as spam, but we can forgive the people on the receiving end of that import for feeling like it was.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-12 00:39

@dammn Yea, we've had some in the past that were absolutely comical. My favorite was one that was something like:

1) I trust I can express my opinion to upper management without fear of retribution.

2) I don't trust I can express my opinion to upper management without fear of retribution.

What answer would you give if you did trust? What answer would you give if you didn't? Absolutely useless poll.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-11 23:16

Someone on our upper management team ran a poll today and it was hilarious in its transparency. The choices were like this:

1) I understand what management is doing and I'm SUPER excited about it.

2) I'm a little hazy what's going on and I'm worried.

3) I don't understand any of this.

There was no option to say you understood but didn't agree. No option to say you were hazy but excited. The only way you say you were concerned about the direction was to say you didn't understand it.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-11 19:15

@shom I got this from Mike Hansen over at #Mycroft (paraphrased). Good information to have moving forward IMHO.

MH: Thanks for the feedback. This is indeed an issue with the current SSML processing pipeline -- prosody tags are best used for full sentences at the moment. The pauses are due to a few different features colliding: automatic punctuation is added when the prosody tags divide up the sentence, so Mimic 3 sees each text chunk is being marked as a complete utterance.

@popey

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-11 18:43

@blackfire Nothing 3rd party, and I'm being more than a little hyperbolic, but there are instructions on the Github page:

https://github.com/MycroftAI/selene-backend

Theoretically with the #Selene backend on prem, any #Mycroft instances pointed to that backend, and a local #Mimic3 install, you can run the whole stack privately and offline. I've never done the whole stack, and Mimic3 is still so new that you have to request the files manually, but I'd love to see this working.

@doomsdayrs @popey

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-11 17:51

@shom Oh, I was using es_ES/m-ailabs_low#karen_savage for the voice config.

@popey

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-11 17:50

@shom I have noticed that adding the prosody volume changes adds pauses to the output too. I assume that's not intentional? I put this in as the input:

<prosody volume="50%">Hola, mi nombre es Miguel. <break time="500ms" />Hablo mal espaÃ±ol.</prosody><voice name="en_UK/apope_low#default"><prosody volume="50%">Thank</prosody>god<prosody volume="50%">for that</prosody></voice>

The results are not good. The Spanish is trashed, and the English pauses for volume changes.

@popey

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-11 17:40

@shom I wasn't super interested in the prosody tag, but I did toy with break times and changing the voice midstream. That did seem to work for everything that I tried, but I only had an American voice speaking a partial phrase and get interrupted by @popey during a predefined pause in the text. Seemed to work perfectly, but everything was English because that's the only language I can claim to speak. Even that I'm not sure I can claim fluency in.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-11 15:59

@blackfire For sure. The biggest obstacle to fully offline Mycroft is just the fact that getting it setup requires several PhDs and a week of time. You can run the backend offline with Selene and configure your speakers to use it, but it's not something that they advertise and it's not something that's a checkbox type config. You really have to dig into the software to get that working. I'd love to see it made easy enough for a person off the street to do it.

@doomsdayrs @popey

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-11 15:57

@popey So far, #Mimic3 seems really good. High quality TTS. When the AP voice tells me "The weather in Phoenix is ^$@%^@ing hot", I almost believe you're the one saying it. Some of the English US voices have an almost Indian accent to them, which is probably something that needs fixing, but overall the 15-20 minutes I've spent with it have been really impressive. Can't install it locally yet, but the fact that you can have a single Mimic3 instance for all your speakers is cool.

@doomsdayrs

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-11 15:53

@doomsdayrs I would love it if the site were overloaded! Not because I want the site to fail, but I'd really like to see some solid interest in VUI products by the open source community. Google and Amazon are running rampant all over this market segment and letting a private company basically wire your house for monitoring seems like a really horrible idea to me. We desperately need a viable open source option here.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-11 15:44

#Mimic3 is finally available for beta testing. It's not a "fully open" test and they send you a link with a generic user/pass combo after you register your email. I assume this is to limit bot traffic and gauge interest. Still looking forward to the #Mycroft #Mark2 in September, and more than likely I'll be using the new @popey voice. I'm still using the original ap voice on my Mark1, and it wouldn't feel natural to use anything else.

https://mycroft.ai/blog/mimic-3-preview/

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-09 16:44

@Sjwillis I hope you get some positive feedback. Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-05 20:45

@Suoko It really would be. #Mycroft has an interesting opportunity in that it's fully open source where if it could stir up some interest from the community, it could literally go anywhere it wants. There's a lot of focus on the whole "Virtual Assistant" thing, and I think that functionality is important, but I would much rather see Mycroft be treated like a VUI. There's a GUI version of Mycroft for KDE, but it's not integrated in any meaningful way. It would be cool to see some effort there.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-05 18:15

@mattbraddock I looked up what it would take to build my own metal detector last night. Crazy things cross our minds sometimes. Not even sure what I'd do with a metal detector if I had one. I'm sure it wouldn't sit in my garage unused, right? I'd be out detecting metal every day for sure.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-05 18:12

@rotfarm Yes. We're so desensitized to advertising and the algorithms that direct our attention on a day to day basis that we don't notice them. When we aren't exposed to them for a while, suddenly they become SUPER obvious. I used to have a clock like that in my house. That thing was CRAZY loud, but I didn't hear it until someone else pointed it out to me because it was just always there. After you notice it again, it takes a while to fade back into the background.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-05 18:09

Just so you know.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-05 16:05

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-05 16:02

@gidorah There's an acronym at my current company that's all over the place. It's used so much it feels like filler. When I started there I asked what the acronym meant, and you could just tell by the look on their face I was going to get an info dump. There's a department, a product, a data warehouse, other things that all use the same acronym. This company is terrible with them. The was literally a team at one point that was (and this is official) called MSHIT. Someone decided M SHIT was good.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-05 15:59

@ankitpati I considered <<that>>, but <<that>> also has some implied distance. You don't use it to describe something you're holding in your hand for example. It just didn't feel right in the moment. Ideally, I feel like both options would have been described as <<this>>, but that could cause confusion in a text based medium. Honestly, there doesn't feel like there's an option that works from all angles.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-05-04 22:42

It's funny in corporations how some things are just flat out lost in time.

Boss: What's ABC acronym stand for?
Me (been with the company 10+ years): Uhhh, <<this>> I think? Let me check.
Me: Hey other guy, what's ABC acronym stand for?
Other guy (been with the company 15+ years): Uhhhh <<this>> maybe? Or maybe <<other this>>?

No one knows.

@joel No, it wasn't that. NekoSock (mew) @NekoSock 2021-03-18 20:18
:boost_ok: :ablobcatwave: Please boost this post if you would like the EFF to join the fediverse. :ablobcatbongo:

In a survey the EFF sent me, I suggested they create an account on the fediverse, so they can reach more supporters and support innovative free software that promotes interoperability among platforms, something they've advocated for in the past, too.

If you can boost this post, maybe I'll be able to show them that there are quite a few users who would like them here!

The EFF is the infamous nonprofit organisation that fights for privacy, government transparency, and digital freedom. Their fight is very important, and the EFF is very special to me. https://www.eff.org/about https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_Frontier_Foundation

You can see some of their work here https://www.eff.org/work

In the meantime, you can follow @eff, which is an unofficial mirror of their Twitter.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-29 22:34

@MorphicOne For you, yes. Home is basically what Twitter is. You follow people, their stuff shows up in your home feed. You can follow anybody from anywhere in the Fed, and it'll show up in your home feed.

@Tay0

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-29 22:33

@MorphicOne Yep, I'd say it does. I think that describes anybody that's ever sat at a keyboard actually. :)

@Tay0

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-29 22:33

@MorphicOne Kind of, but only because we have access to our local feed of posts. Otherwise, you have as much access to an individual on Fosstodon as I do. You can follow them just like I can, etc.

@Tay0

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-29 22:32

@MorphicOne Koyu has it's own local feed that is just posts by people who are members of the community on Koyu. 3/3

@Tay0

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-29 22:30

@MorphicOne both Mastodon instances in the Fed. They both can potentially see the same information in the Fed, but they're controlled by different people and may have different rules. Fosstodon is specifically for fans of free and open source software, so that's a requirement of being a member of our community. Because of that, our local feed is made up of some really interesting and amazing stuff relating to Free software. The local feed is ONLY posts that are made on Fosstodon. 2/

@Tay0

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-29 22:28

@MorphicOne So the way Mastodon works (and many other similar services) is kind of like email. There's a whole lot of Mastodon servers (called instances) out there. Each one of those instances is capable of acting on it's own, and the software is open source and freely available. Those instances connect to each other like a giant fishing net, so there is no "main" instance. Each is as important as the next. This net is called the Fediverse (Fed for short). Fosstodon and Koyu are 1/

@Tay0

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-29 21:52

@Tay0 We really have. Not sure how we got so lucky with #Fosstodon. It's been an amazing trip. Can't wait to see where it takes us in the future.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-29 16:28

@dammn Is there a way? I would posit that it can be done. I don't think anybody has taken the plunge so far. Mastodon (and compatible platforms) is open enough that pretty much anybody can write an app that will read/write posts. It would just need a converter to push it out to #gemini. Heck, profiles have their own RSS feeds, so really all you'd need to do is export out your follow list and have an RSS to gemini converter. I don't know if that exists already, but it seems more than plausible.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-29 04:50

@Cleoqc I agree, that would be really hard, which is why our CoC doesn't require that. Ultimately, if you're on Fosstodon then it's our CoC that you most have to worry about. About the only time the "English Only" comes into play is when you're creating a new post that's going to be published to the local timeline. Replies or DMs or non-public posts don't require English. That being said, that's about the only part of the CoC that DOESN'T apply all the time.

@arejula27 At present a DM is just a standard message that just happens to be directly sent to another individual or group of individuals. There's no encryption or anything like that for the time being. Encryption is a feature that is actively being worked on, so in the not too distant future what I'm telling you now will be wrong. Not sure when that will be, but it's slated for 2022.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-28 15:51

@Cleoqc Hi, so regarding the non-English posting, here's the deal. "English Only" applies to posts that show up in the public timelines. I don't know how much you've had a chance to play around with posting permissions, but there's (probably) a globe on the toolbar right below where you type. If you click that there's a couple different options. Public, Unlisted, Followers-Only, and Direct. The "English Only" rule only applies to Public posts. Any language you choose can be used for the rest.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-27 19:06

@chrisjrob We're not going to say that you can't post that kind of stuff here. Fosstodon isn't just for tech, it's for people who are fans of open source software. That's not 100% of your life. There are certain hot button issues like religion and politics that we'd prefer to be behind a CW. People seeking that kind of conversation out can find it, and no one else has to suffer through it if they don't want to. It shouldn't be the majority of what gets posted though.

@evolved_robonaut Yea, it's pretty cool. You can create lists and add columns for those lists as well as track hashtags (multiple per column if you choose). Really cool UI in my opinion.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-27 17:40

@gloopsies It's a preference in your actual account, so other clients SHOULD respect it. I can't promise that but the official app will respect it and so will the more main stream. Personally, I just use the PWA on my mobile device and it works great.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-27 17:28

@tulpa Not sure how to quantify how big the hosting is now. We have 80 Sidekiq threads going. We more than tripled our resources yesterday.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-27 17:24

@tulpa Right now all our queues are clear and Fosstodon looks like it's up to date. It is a federated network though, so remote instances lagging may look like lagging on Fosstodon. So far it looks like yesterday's upgrades have been able to keep pace with the influx of new members. We're keeping a pretty close watch on things right now to make sure.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-27 17:20

@wook It doesn't actually translate, but I think most people that do that are using some kind of cross poster. When they post on Twitter, that post gets mirrored on Fosstodon, and the handle gets converted to @handle@twitter.com. It's not actually a thing though.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-27 17:18

@nativebreed Depends I guess. Some people (me and @kev and others) really like having our own instances. I've also seen people migrate off Fosstodon to their own private instance and then come back later because they didn't like it. "Better" would be a really subjective measure.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-27 17:17

@nativebreed Nope.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-27 17:17

@nativebreed Depends on the server. If (hypothetically) you violate the CoC on Fosstodon and get your account suspended, there's a grace period for you to migrate off. If you don't, your account gets deleted permanently and that gets propagated out to the Fediverse. You lose your stuff. If you migrate off your old profile goes away, but you live a long happy life on another instance.

If another instance deletes your account, you probably don't even notice unless it's one of the bigger ones.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-27 17:14

@nativebreed A couple answers here.

Your posts do replicate across the Fed. For example, if you search for "MikeStone", you can still see my old profile on mastodon.rocks from before @kev and I created Fosstodon. mastodon.rocks is no longer in existence, but my old profile is still discoverable.

Regarding the server going down, we published our Promise to you on our support page here:

https://hub.fosstodon.org/support/

We have no plans on shutting Fosstodon down, but we have contingency plans anyway.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-27 17:04

@gloopsies If you go into your settings, Preferences -> Other, there's an option to check your preferred language for public timelines. It won't help if someone decides to DM you, but for the Local timeline here on Fosstodon and the Fed, should filter out some stuff for you.

@JoeRess @felimwhiteley Another way to use Twitter through RSS is using Nitter. No accounts required and you can add multiple accounts you want to follow just by adding a comma separated list. Super easy and can be added to pretty much any RSS reader.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-25 16:09

@kev I'm surprised there's not a more open solution to this. From a high level perspective all you should really need is a web page (which you have) with an RSS feed (which you have), and email box (which you have), and a seemingly small script that would monitor the mailbox for subscribe/unsubscribe activity and send out new emails based on RSS activity. I know I'm oversimplifying this by a lot, but it doesn't feel like this whole thing should be all that complicated.

That would be a deal breaker for me, but for people not tied to the local feed of their particular instance, it's a workable client.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-21 20:47

Testing out the new Official Mastodon client on Android. It's pretty decent. The UI is nice, but I really miss my Local timeline. Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-21 19:11

@hakerdefo It's pretty good. It makes a lot of assumptions about what you want to do, and that's great when it it's right, but sometimes it does some funky things based on those assumptions. In general, good with some quirks.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-21 18:25

What kind of day is it you ask?

I updated an alias I have in my .bash_aliases file. I save and exit, reload the shell, and it doesn't work. I check the file, do it all again, and it doesn't work. Literally more than 10 minutes later I finally realize I'm using fish not bash.

That's the kind of day it is.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-21 03:18

@cassidyjames I guess it depends. Is the goal of Mastodon to be a Twitter analog where the majority of users are on a few enormous instances with a bare smattering of others on tiny satellite instances, or is the goal to decentralize the population and encourage people to branch beyond a centralized setup? If it's the former, ignoring what makes instances unique is a good way to go. If it's the later, then features that make instances interesting and different should be highlighted.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-21 02:43

@cassidyjames I'm not sure tailoring the experience with extremely large instances in mind is the best approach. I would be so bold to say that the local timeline is very manageable/beneficial on an instance the size of #Fosstodon, and we have ~20000 people in our community. We're larger than 99% of Mastodon instances. It seems these large instances are the exception, not the rule, and the software should be tailored with that in mind.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-20 07:22

@joseph Yes it does.

It's great to see so many new names and faces over the last week. If you're new here or just feeling like a refresher, please do read our Code of Conduct for #Fosstodon as we are not just an open source version of Twitter, and the rules ARE different here.

https://hub.fosstodon.org/coc

If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to ask myself, @kev, or any one of our moderation team. We're all happy to help.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-18 20:39

@coffe Naw, that's not how that works. If you only had a couple people on your instance it would be fine. Processes get queued and once the active one is done it automatically moves to the next. All if it happens in the background and unless something seriously goes sideways you won't even notice.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-18 19:32

@allinone0 Trust? What is this "trust" you speak of?

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-18 19:31

@gabor Not that I know of. If someone else chimes in with something that does this I'd be interested to see it. We can see a very limited window of time in the Admin console, but as far as I know that's it. It doesn't even have relevant information on the graph.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-18 19:26

@tulpa Does that make me half European? I make both with an electric appliance.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-18 01:19

@w96k No, we have no plans on banning people based on their nationality.

One of our goals stated in our CoC is to "provide a friendly, safe, and welcoming environment for everyone interested in Free/Libre/Open-Source Software, regardless of ... nationality, political affiliation...".

We do have a general dislike of politics. We like to keep discussion of them to a minimum and covered by CW.

Honestly, we wouldn't even know if you're Russian or not if you didn't tell us.

PaulaToThePeople @PaulaToThePeople 2022-04-15 22:49

Did you know there are centralized alternatives to the #Fediverse?

They are great!
Instead of being developed by volunteers for the community they are developed for millionaires with the sole purpose of getting them more money and influence over the "users".

They contain ads and algorithms, so you don't have to decide, what you want to see, but you get to see what makes you addicted, so you view more ads, buy more stuff and thereby support the capitalist system that we all love.

Instead of anonymity you get to enter your phone number and other form of identification, which totally helps against hate speech, right?

I could go on with advantages, but I think it's best you check them out for yourselves.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-17 19:54

@jarbus While I doubt many would describe my site as "beautiful", it's decent and I use Jekyll for it.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-16 02:21

@bjb I actually ran across an article in the local "paper" about it.

https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/karinabland/2019/04/26/car-battery-life-unmercifully-short-arizona-karina-bland/3589315002/

Yes, I'm aware it's a dry heat. :)

@MrDers

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-16 02:18

@bjb The short answer is "it's really hot".

The longer answer isn't much better. In the summer temperatures here in Phoenix can get to 120F (~50C). Temperatures like that can mess with voltage regulators, which can cause the battery to get overcharged. Add to that the fact that batteries contain water which evaporates and messes with the internal chemical composition and the fact that extreme of temperature just flat out breaks down the materials the batteries are made from.

@MrDers

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-16 00:50

@MrDers Yea, it's crazy. It's why I buy my batteries through AAA. It comes with a 3 year warranty, so I know I'll get 4 years of battery out of just one buy because the original will die miserably after 2 years and they'll have to replace it with a new one. That one will last 2 years, and then I'll have to pay again.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-15 22:39

@MrDers Honestly, I'd love it if my car battery lasted 3 years. That would be amazing. I have to replace mine every 2 at the most. Deserts do that.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-15 20:29

@tulpa @tulpa Yea, that's a security "feature" of Mastodon. Not only can accounts not be reused, but email addresses can't be reused either. If an account existed at some point with an email address, that email can't be used to signup again. Even the admins can't change that setting without forking Mastodon itself and revising the code. Sorry for the inconvenience.

@cooper @kev

@JRLarsen I was never in the Marine Corps and I'm still hesitant to step on wet/cleaned floors.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-14 23:10

@krosylight Ah, yea. That's not total ever, that's just how much we have on hand. We keep 6 months of operating costs on hand at all times, and when enough builds up beyond that 6 months we donate that to an open source project. We take suggestions from the community and the people that donate vote.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-14 20:35

@xpil I've never spent much time on the Locals of other instances, but I avoid the Fed as much as I can. My Home timeline is pretty decent as I've been pretty selective about who I follow. It's very similar to the Fosstodon Local timeline, only it's mostly people from other instances. I think it's unfortunate that there's so much focus on the Home timeline when the Local is so awesome here, but I understand the reasoning when the person making that call is on a large general instance.

@kev @ru

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-14 20:32

@celia Let me expand on what @kev said. We have no philosophical reason we settled on 500. It's the Mastodon default, and the configuration for that is not easily reachable. Because of that it makes it impractical for us to change it. If the configuration of the toot length was moved to a simple text box in the Admin pages we could update at will, I don't think we'd have problems with 1000 character toots. I don't think that Eugen has any plans to make that kind of change though.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-14 20:25

@Gina I think people in Australia are people like everybody else.

@killyourfm

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-13 19:11

@tagmenot Not really. It's not a big deal. It's just a warning because the way you've been posting has been coming across as "spammy" to some of members of the community. It happens sometimes when you post several links in a row and/or don't interact with the community much. It makes the account look like it's a link aggregator. I'd suggest spacing out posts a little and post some things that aren't just links with descriptions.

@Tay0 Well, I'm lazy so I pay someone else to do it. I don't have grass, but they keep the trees and bushes nicely trimmed and make sure weeds don't take things over.

@Gina

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-13 15:54

@Gina Hard to say. I'm far from a lawn expert. I don't have any grass in my yard either. Since Easter is so close, I'm assuming you're going to go with a turf option. It won't have near the time to grow naturally. Turf usually requires some "settling in" time but as long as it's mostly under furniture and people aren't actively walking on it the whole time, it'll probably be OK? It'll need some care afterwards though.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-13 15:10

@Gina Grass would probably be nice as long as there's not so much traffic that your Easter brunch destroys what you've just planted. Also, make sure you don't plant the grass where the evil Ring mirror can see it or it'll get sucked into the nether realms. :blobcatwinktongue:

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-13 15:05

@2501 Oh, I'm sorry. There's nothing I can do. Once an account is deleted, Mastodon removes everything. I can see the account was there and that it's been deleted, but that's it. We can't bring it back.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-07 20:43

@joel The release notes state this:

"Since older Mastodon versions would not understand the edits, the function is disabled in the web app until more Mastodon servers upgrade to 3.5, but all parts are already included in the release."

There are only a handful of instances that are on 3.5 at this point. I think a good number of them were waiting on some issues to be resolved first. That's why Fosstodon wasn't upgraded before. Once we start to see more uptake that feature will be enabled.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-05 19:47

@me I agree, and it becomes a self perpetuating cycle. No one uses it because no one uses it. That's why I encourage you to start with friends and families. Your presence means they've got at least SOME foothold in the ecosystem. The more you can convince the more motivation others have to join.

@wswartzendruber

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-05 18:44

@cfcosta I do think people could adapt. I think that any platform with a population like Twitter's is going to be chaotic, but Twitter profits from that chaos and actually pushes it algorithmically. Without that push to chaos added in, I think the Fediverse would still be able to maintain a semblance of sanity compared to Twitter. Smaller, more focused communities would be even better than general instances like mastodon.social just due to moderation tools and a smaller community to moderate.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-04-05 17:47

So, Elon Musk has become a significant shareholder in Twitter. Jack Dorsey has said he regrets his role in centralizing the Internet. Net change? I'm guessing minimal. Twitter will keep sucking, and people will complain about Twitter sucking but use it anyway. OR, they could move to a better alternative like Mastodon. I realize I'm preaching to the choir posting about Mastodon on Mastodon, but still. Tell your friends.

@stardust That's hard unfortunately. We can theoretically remove emoji on our instance, but we have no control over the visibility or existence of emoji on other instances. Mike Stone @mike 2022-03-15 15:59

@spyro No, that's a Mastodon feature. Replies to your own toots are considered a thread, so the entirety of the thread is posted to the timeline if you're using Public permissions on the toots.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-03-13 07:50

@sotolf The TV/Movie thing is why watching a movie or TV show adapted from a book I've already read is hard for me. It's like recasting/remaking the whole thing from someone else's perspective. The people that were there before get replaced by new faces. It sucks even more because it's hard to get those faces out of my head if I read that book again.

@hq1

Mike Stone @mike 2022-03-13 07:43

@sotolf For me it kind of depends on what I'm reading. A novel about people and scenarios I kind of build a movie for it in my head. It all plays out visually. If it's more instructional, it's basically the same as reading it out loud.

@hq1

Mike Stone @mike 2022-03-13 07:23

Mike Stone @mike 2022-03-13 06:39

Mike Stone @mike 2022-03-09 01:09

@cal Oh, I'm sorry. I thought that restriction was just for Followers Only. I apologize for the bad information.

@cooper @Yid @kev @fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2022-03-09 00:04

@cal They don't show up in the Fed timeline, but any individual in the Fediverse can see them if they look at your profile or they follow you directly. Hash tags in those posts will be part of search results for anybody, so adding something like #Yiddish would make them easily found. Further, people can create columns for those hashes in their UI so they don't have to search. I have several columns like that in my default UI

@cooper @Yid @kev @fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2022-03-08 23:56

@cal You're welcome to stay on Fosstodon if you would like. We only ask the posts made to our public timelines be made in English. If you would like to post in Yiddish, please switch to an unlisted or followers only permission level. That's all we're asking. If this is too much, then other instances in the Fediverse are less restrictive than we are. Possibly floss.social or mastodon.technology are instances that may fit your interests.

@cooper @Yid @kev @fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2022-03-08 23:50

@cal Apologies if this sounds insensitive, but Fosstodon is for fans free and open source software, not for fans of rare languages. We're also not for fans of astronomy or custom engine modification. It's an instance with a specific focus, not a general instance like mastodon.social. We ask that posts to our public timeline be done in English to ease our moderation, which keeps an instance of roughly 20K people from going bonkers. I understand your frustration.

@Yid @kev @fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2022-03-08 23:42

@Yid Yes, you can toot without being public. The globe at the bottom of your posts allows you to change the groups you're posting to. The globe is everybody, and that shows up in public timelines. There's Unlisted, which anybody can see but doesn't show up in the local or federated timelines, Followers Only which only people following you can see. There's also Direct, which is self explanatory.

@kev @cal @fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2022-03-08 23:30

@_failsafe I'm going to try to make it all week. I don't know when the last time was that I hadn't used a computer for that long. It's probably been literal decades. Quite possibly since the 90s. Of course, I'm kind of cheating by using my phone. I'm still able to do most "computer" tasks this way. Just very little of the baggage.

@kev

Cooper :tor: :sadkev: @cooper 2022-02-17 16:31

A warm "welcome!" to all of our new members. Whether you're new to new to Mastodon or just new to Fosstodon, we're glad you joined.

For those members (new and old) that don't know, https://hub.fosstodon.org/ is full of information that is relative to our instance. From staff members to our Code of Conduct, you can find more information about Fosstodon! Make sure to check it out and, if you haven't already done so, make sure tell us a bit about yourself.

#fosstodon #introductions

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-17 16:16

@jiminycricket The interesting thing is that it's not necessarily "average". Feature uniformity is one of the things psychologists have pointed to as something that makes faces attractive.

Sorta side note: I used to work for a gaming company that had a Psychology department whose job it was to determine how to get people to play more and longer. I could see something similar in the future for AI generated spokespeople. Entire departments of people trying to game the human mind with AI.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-17 15:58

@RyuKurisu While I love the line of thought, I'm not sure how that would stop the technology that allows for AI generated faces and deep fakes. To the contrary, open sourcing the tech would just let everybody do it, and probably make it better than closed source options.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-17 15:33

AI generated faces have been shown to be more "trustworthy" in surveys. This is interesting in and of itself.

Dr Sophie Nightingale, who is a Lecturer in Psychology at Lancaster University in the UK says "Itâ€™s just going to get worse if we donâ€™t do something to stop it."

I'm curious to hear how she thinks we can "stop" it.

This is now. What kind of results are we going to get in ten years? People are going to be able to do better than this on their phones.

Thoughts?

https://www.newscientist.com/article/2308312-fake-faces-created-by-ai-look-more-trustworthy-than-real-people/

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-17 15:06

@Gina The thing that boggles me is a complete lack of awareness. I get those same kind of calls, and it's almost always some year long contract to fix some companies desktop computers for a base level salary. I work full time on enterprise class servers. Why the hell would I want to spend my days clearing out the cookies on some rando's browser? I'm not even super fond of fixing the enterprise class servers. Oh, and I already make more than twice that salary doing it. So.... why??

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-17 03:26

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-16 21:50

@macxool I've only recently started getting into it, so my own experience is pretty shallow, but it can control lights and smart switches. Thermostats, etc. Of course Home Assistant has a pretty decent API, so you can code your own skills to interact with it in new and interesting ways. However you see fit. That's really one of my favorite bits about Mycroft. The whole thing is open. It's even got "Companion" projects, like HiveMind that are pretty neat options.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-16 20:34

@macxool Well, there are many "skills" that can be downloaded with a wide variety of functions. One of the bigs is integration with Home Assistant. You can control pretty much any aspect of a smart home. Ignoring the downloadable skills, it's open source. You can make it do anything you want. Control a robot. Tell you the temperature of your swimming pool. Read a value from a personal database. Hell, I've got a skill that, when you ask it how many lights there are, says There are four lights.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-16 20:19

Looks like #Mycroft is still expecting to hit their September 19th shipping start date, though they do make me nervous when they say things like this: "The remaining open parts are only held up as we assess a few potential improvements (camera and display)." NO. You're 4 years late. Stop screwing with things and ship a damn product! There's always going to be an improvement here or a tweak there. JUST SHIP THE PRODUCT.

https://mycroft.ai/blog/mycroft-manufacturing-and-product-update-3/

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-16 18:17

@xpil That part actually doesn't matter. The question was more whether you're using the web interface (advanced or otherwise) or some other kind of UI from some other location. Brutaldon or an Android/iOS app, etc. "Firefox" kinda answers that question, but are you using the advanced web interface, or the other one, or some other web frontend?

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-16 17:49

@xpil Depends on the UI I guess. Some of the apps allow for it's removal.

IMHO, the Fed is the reason some apps/developers who shall remain nameless have been removing the Federated and Local timelines. The Fed is a complete dumpster fire which I'm sure was very useful when the population of Mastodon numbered in the thousands not the millions. Huge instances like mastodon.social have the same issue with their local feeds for the same reasons. Thankfully #Fosstodon has an awesome local feed.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-15 17:26

@randynose @Tay0 They certainly won't have a shortage if they migrate even just the short distance stuff to automation. All they're doing so far around here is between Tucson and Phoenix, which is only around 90 miles (145KM). If that's successful, they can add more cities, probably in the south west, but the south in general won't be far behind. Then, as the AIs get better, they'll move north. Pretty soon they'll only need a handful of drivers with a pulse.

@Tay0 I expect that with all these shortages and political activism, headlines like this one will become pretty commonplace in the pretty near future.

https://www.fox10phoenix.com/news/autonomous-trucker-tusimple-logs-first-no-human-road-test-in-arizona1

The company in question here, TuSimple, says that drivers represent about 40% of all trucking operational costs and that its virtual driver "can be operated for significantly less." Not to mention no holidays, sick leave, sleep, or bathroom breaks required.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-10 15:01

@kev Might be, depending. I get about 40Mbps faster on my phone's 5G connection than my home, but I'm not on Fiber either. There's also other things to take into consideration. For me, it would be data caps and the fact that I have a business line so I can have static IPs and other more business features. Most of those I don't use other than the static. If none of that matters for you, 4G (5G??) might be an option for you. Sounds like your copper is going to be a problem moving forward.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-10 14:56

@thisisfilber7 There's built in adblocking with several different layers of granularity. Beyond that it's also a Chromium based browser, so the majority of addons that work with Google Chrome or Firefox work in Vivaldi. Personally I have the integrated blocker at maximum, and then I have Privacy Essentials addon installed too. Mostly I think all that addon does is put the grade up in my address bar, but I don't notice any intrusive ads. In fairness, don't spend a lot of time on YouTube though.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-10 02:20

@unicornfarts So far it's been really cool. My only complaint about it so far is that it's not in the mobile version yet. I'd love to be able to have something on my phone and save it to the Reading List and open it on my computer, or the inverse. The Reading List syncs between computers, so I'm guessing it's a matter of time. This could be the feature that breaks my tab habit.

@parasurv

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-10 00:05

@sanchez Oh, mine would be super packed if I did that. I'd lose track of so much stuff. I usually just end up leaving the tabs open, which is why I have a billion tabs open.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-09 21:59

@QuinnBMORE Welcome Quinn!

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-09 21:28

@parasurv Yea, and that's an area where Vivaldi isn't exactly stellar either. In the plus column it has a feature where you can simply right click and choose Hibernate Background Tabs, which unloads those tabs from memory. It can help if you're a tab horder like myself. When you use the browser with only a handful of tabs, it's pretty good. When you've got 50+ open at all times like I do things can get a bit more bloated. That feature is really handy.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-09 20:00

@parasurv More than just the devs actually. The CEO and founder of Vivaldi is JÃ³n S. von Tetzchner, who along with Geir IvarsÃ¸y originally developed Opera and was the one who really brought Opera to the masses. He has since left Opera and founded Vivaldi, but Vivaldi is working to bring all the best of Opera to Vivaldi.

The fact is, Vivaldi is "mostly" open source. There's a big long explanation for it from someone who knows the details better than me:

https://vivaldi.com/blog/technology/why-isnt-vivaldi-browser-open-source/

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-09 18:40

There's a new version of #Vivaldi Browser out today.

https://vivaldi.com/new/

I know it's not fully open source and it's Chromium based, which makes it a non-starter for some, but there's some pretty cool new features in 5.1. :vivaldi: Vivaldi is pushing hard on the horizontal tab scrolling, but for me the Reading List is the big seller. I don't need the horizontal tab scrolling if I have a reading list.
