Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-07 22:38

@sotolf It absolutely is. We don't mind accounts that mirror Twitter posts or even automate some of their posting, but they need to at the very least be interactive. If they're not interacting with the community, they're just noise. A warning has already been sent for their spam from this morning, and we're going to follow up to make sure their either interactive with their account or find a new home.

@kev @hund

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-07 21:41

@sotolf Bot accounts do exist here, but they should be monitored, and they're generally not supposed to post to the public timelines. Solidity mixes whether they post Public or Unlisted based on content, and they're usually pretty good about that distinction. Today was not one of those times.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-04 05:04

@damko I might be younger. Hard to tell. We didn't have TV for quite a while. Well, that's not true. Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-03 23:31

@bbbhltz Yep, we used to light up some candles when the power went out and call and make sure all of our neighbors were alright. Everybody was good for heat (in the winter obviously) and that kind of stuff. Then you'd sit around playing board games or go to bed early.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-03 23:29

@damko Thankfully didn't have that for the most part. That antenna was heavy, and it took some real effort to move. My uncle had a similar setup, but his had a hand crank on it to help with the turning. We just rotated ours by hand. The best part was people inside yelling at you. STOP! MORE! BACK TO WHERE YOU WERE BEFORE!! THAT'S WORSE, GO BACK!! STOP!! NO, KEEP GOING!!

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-03 23:07

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-03 23:05

@damko Oh man, when I was a kid I used to live here:

https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/5523951

We had an antenna attached to the side of our house, and when we changed channels on the TV, we had to go outside and rotate the antenna to point in a different direction per channel. Talk about a nightmare during the winter. You'd just watch a show because hell no I'm not going out there.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-03 23:03

@devinprater Heh, a DVD player IS a special player for today's teens. When he watches Netflix, he usually starts a movie on the bus ride home, and when he gets home he just hits stop, turns on the TV, opens the Netflix app, and starts the movie right where he left off. No players or discs or anything. The idea that Netflix used to send something physical to you that you needed to put into a player made him laugh out loud.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-02-03 22:41

My wife and I just had to explain to my teen how phones at one point needed to be plugged into a wall. Oh, and Netflix used to actually mail you a disc that you'd watch in a special player and then mail back.

I feel SUPER old right now.

@harmathy It's not doing badly actually. I heard there was some concerns about it, but the only keys that seem to have any pressure issues are the Esc and Bksp, which are the very ends of the top row. Everything else seems fine. I'll keep this in mind if it gets to be annoying.

Mastodon @Mastodon 2022-01-31 17:37

âš ï¸ We are planning to release important security fixes for #Mastodon on February 3rd, between 13:00 and 15:00 UTC.

To make sure that most servers can upgrade swiftly, we will release the fixes both as v3.3.2 and v3.4.6 (they will, of course, be also available on the main branch).

To make sure the upgrades on those older versions require the least intervention, with just a process restart, we have just released preparatory releases v3.3.1 and v3.4.5.

Please upgrade!

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-25 23:07

@adamsdesk@mastodon.technology At this point, there's very little reason to ask. The answer is yes. As of January 2022, an estimated 6.64 billion people have smartphones. The VAST majority of those phones are either Android or iPhones, and both of those platforms listen to you unless it's been otherwise specified. I'd be willing to bet that more than 95% of those people DON'T turn off their "assistant". So, even if YOU don't have a smartphone, or you've disabled the assistant on one, you're still being listened to.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-25 18:48

@tychosoft That sounds like an amazing idea!

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-25 18:38

This is why I'm so supportive of 3rd party services like #Mycroft. This app isn't even required. It's a shortcut, and it still has a billion installs. Google listens to billions of people, all the time. The amount of data this allows them to gather on everyone, not just users of their devices, is unfathomable.

https://www.androidpolice.com/google-assistant-app-installs-double-to-1-billion-in-just-7-months/

@pheonix

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-24 17:18

@pheonix No, I think that's a solid point. Previously my company provided perks in the office. Coffee stations and a gym and a cafeteria. They also have normal stuff, like janitorial staff and bathrooms for the employees and things like that. None of that is required when employees are working from home. All of it "saves" money. Working from home means the company can save money on expenses and get more from its employees. I can see why they'd be less motivated to return to "normal".

@MrDers

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-24 16:59

@pheonix @MrDers My question is, is that "pre-pandemic culture" going to restart at all? Prior to COVID, there was a lot of concern about whether or not working from home was a viable strategy. COVID kind of forced the hands of many corporations. The end results were pretty positive in that many firms found their employees worked more and were more productive from home than the office. It's not easy justifying a full return to office because of that. Plus, many employees like working from home.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-24 16:37

@MrDers Hard to say. Many are going back, but there's a lot of people that are staying home. My company literally rented out our office space. Seems to imply we're not going to be back in the office any time soon.

@fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-13 02:15

@DarkWraithLord@mastodon.social Yea, my rhythms are non-existent. I have a terrible time sleeping right up until I'm fall down exhausted. Then I just get as much sleep as I can get at a stretch and do it all over again. It's SUPER unhealthy. I'm getting to be an age where I need to be paying much closer attention to my personal health.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-13 02:13

@technicalissues I'm not even sure to be honest. I'm considered a generalist in my current position, and most of my work is process automation dealing with file transfer and encryption. I'm to the point where if I have to decrypt another file I just my throw my computer in the trash after bludgeoning it into itty bitty pieces. I used to be more hands on in my work. Everything from running fiber to racking systems. Not sure I'd want to go back to that now either. I can say NO to full time coding.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-13 02:11

@wholesomedonut I pretty much always use my real name, but my real name is only a couple steps away from John Smith, so it's not as big of a deal as it could be.

@Phate6660

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-12 21:25

@jordan31 Hm, we make a concerted effort to keep political topics to a minimum on Fosstodon. Obviously there's often a crossover with politics and technology, and we try not to be too restrictive if people are correctly using CWs. Sorry to hear you're not having a great experience.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-12 21:23

@cosullivan It's something we take into consideration every time an instance block comes up. We haven't taken any such action with mastodon.sdf.org, and as far as I know it's not on our radar to do so. When we do defederate with an instance, we definitely look at how large that instance is and how many of our members follow individuals from that instance. Obviously can't speak for other admins around the Fed though.

@claudiom@mastodon.sdf.org @encelado

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-11 21:26

@marquiskurt IMHO this exact conversation is why. The company and individuals within their communities can still claim that Apple isn't outright BLOCKING other OSs from their hardware, where functionally they're doing exact that by withholding information that would make other OSs feasible. In short, PR. I expect in the future that Apple will cease doing even that considering they're making it harder and harder over time.

@JoeRess @8none1 @felimwhiteley @degville @kev @LateNightLinux

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-11 21:01

@degville @LateNightLinux @kev @8none1 @felimwhiteley @JoeRess

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-11 20:45

@marquiskurt Heh, I've seen Apple "change it's mind" to the detriment of their "friends" several times. And I'm not even including times where Apple ripped off ideas from the App store for their own apps in house apps. They're moving more and more in house. Apple's lack of openness makes compatibility harder for anybody that's not Apple. Linux worked pretty well on pre-M1 Apple hardware. How does it work on Apple's new hardware?

@8none1 @kev @LateNightLinux @felimwhiteley @degville @JoeRess

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-11 20:03

@marquiskurt "Apple all evil"? Not sure. I am sure that AT BEST, Apple is apathetic to the Linux community. As long as it's not taking a penny away from their bottom line, they're fine with it. They're not going to help in any significant way, but they're not going to blow the whole thing up either. I just have no faith that's going to last. As soon as Apple feels it's in their best interest to nuke the Linux community, they will.

@felimwhiteley @LateNightLinux @kev @degville @JoeRess @8none1

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-11 18:23

@marquiskurt See, and that's the problem isn't it? Barely over a year ago Linus Torvalds was saying he doubted Linux would ever be ported fully to the M1. Why?

"Apple won't be forthcoming with sufficient detail about the M1 System on Chip (SoC) for Linux kernel developers to build first-class support."

https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2020/11/__trashed-6/

Apple is "helping" because Apple won't help. Not exactly an example of full throated support here.

@kev @8none1 @LateNightLinux @JoeRess @degville @felimwhiteley

Mike Stone boosted
FediTips has moved! @feditips 2022-01-11 17:03

The Fediverse is more than just Mastodon! :fediverse:

If you like to share photos you might want to check out @pixelfed, an Instagram-style photo sharing network on the Fediverse.

You can find out more and sign up at:

https://pixelfed.org

PixelFed uses the same federation protocol as Mastodon, which means Mastodon users can follow people on PixelFed and vice versa. You can try following a PixelFed account right now such as @Iancylkowski or @JoseMel or @connyduck

You can use PixelFed through a web browser, and there are also free open Android apps like @PixelDroid and FediLab (@apps).

#Fediverse #FediTips #Instagram #Alternatives #PixelFed

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-11 17:31

@benjaminhollon I have to admit, the customize toolbar feature is pretty slick. It's not enough for me to switch, but it's a feature I wish Vivaldi had. Honestly, it feels weird that it doesn't considering the EXTREME customizability of virtually everything else.

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-11 16:49

@marquiskurt I'll answer this question with a question. Why does Apple NEED to help? Linux has been ported handily to everything from super computers to graphing calculators. The M1 is at its core an ARM processor, which Linux has run on for years. So what's making the M1 such a tough nut to crack?

@kev @felimwhiteley @degville @LateNightLinux @JoeRess @8none1

Mike Stone @mike 2022-01-08 01:59

@bjhess Sounds like a plan. Moving from one instance to another has gotten relatively easy as of late. You can move over your followers and all that jazz and have people who have been following you automatically moved over to the other account. The only thing I'd caution against is deleting the old account. If you ever want to come back for ANY reason, once an account is deleted, it's GONE. Not even the admins can bring it back. Ever.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-30 00:34

@normandc We've been driving our minivan almost exclusively, but it's a Hybrid, so it gets pretty good gas mileage.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-30 00:24

Hm, I put gas in my car today. I haven't put gas in my car since the 16th of November.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-29 02:17

@trhr I don't think the claim that people tend to stick to their own instance has been established as fact, and I think the Federated timeline being a dumpster fire has nothing to do with it. Point in fact, there is no analog for either the Fed or the Local timeline on Twitter. Your Home timeline is what Twitter is. Your Home timeline is built by follows, and follows are easily across the Fediverse.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-29 00:35

@kev Honestly, I use Feedly. You can use it for free if you don't mind it sticking advertising in the middle of your feeds, but you can pay for a subscription if you want to not worry about that crap. It's got a nice Web UI, and native apps on both Android and iOS. I don't think you can use Reeder with it though.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-29 00:29

@trhr There's no "fragmentation" that would stop one of or members from following anyone on those instances, being it a 21 year old college student with questions about Ruby or Katy Perry trying to interact with her fans. 3/3

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-29 00:27

@trhr Instances that are more general in their subject matter and don't stick to particular topics branch out significantly more. That being said, even Fosstodon knows about a massive number of instances. Last I checked. Fosstodon was "aware" of almost 15K instances, and I don't know how many users on those instances. All the users on all those instances are available to Fosstodon community members. 2/

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-29 00:24

@trhr I agree that a user couldn't get 100K boosts on the Fed today. That's just due to population, nothing else really.

If 200 million people joined the Fed, they would more than likely not join the same instance.

If an influencer joined the Fed, I think they would absolutely get access to the full 200 million people. I don't think the Fed is as isolated as you think it is. Instances like Fosstodon can give that impression because they're specific to a subject. 1/

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-28 23:33

@trhr I don't think that's true. I get that people use Twitter because people are using Twitter. That's a whole chicken/egg argument that we see over and over in multiple scenarios. BUT, there's nothing about "fragmentation" in the Fediverse that would prevent engagement from occurring.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-28 20:06

@trhr Which is where the home timeline and notifications come in. I know almost no one that uses the fed, that doesn't stop people from interacting based on actual content. When I post something and I get interaction, I doubt that interaction is coming from people seeing my post in the Fed. The majority of the time it's from people that see my post in the Local timeline, or who follow me directly. I see their replies in my notifications, not in the Fed.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-28 19:53

@popey Let's be honest, I'm not going to be the only one that doesn't follow directions.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-28 19:53

@trhr What's happened/is happening with Parler has nothing to do with the algorithm. It has to do with moderation policy. That's also relevant to your other comment about duplicating the local timeline. Twitter could pseudo-replicate the functionality, but they can't replicate the moderation policy differences on individual instances. What you're allowed to post here is different than what you're allowed to post on noagenda.social. Twitter can not/will not replicate that capability.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-28 19:23

@trhr Which brings us full circle back to Aral's post. Those people would get better interaction on Mastodon than Twitter, so they should be checking here.

The long and short of it is this. Twitter's algorithm works for Twitter. No one else. Not big names, not the people trying to get the attention of those big names. It works for Twitter.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-28 08:18

@xpil My wife's response: "Oh look, a DIY defibrillator!"

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-28 05:01

@giantspacesquid Are the dials wired in and functional, or is it purely voice driven?

@adamsdesk@mastodon.technology

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-28 01:20

@trhr If you want the Katie Courics or Jeremy Clarksons to repeat your message, they have to see it first. That algorithm is working against you.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-27 22:58

@m33 When you say, "because of how the fediverse is meshed", do you mean because not all instances know about each other?

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-27 22:32

@m33 I'm not quite sure what you're saying here. Can you elaborate?

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-27 22:22

This is something we need people with bigger audiences to realize. Sure, Twitter has that "special sauce" that just keeps you scrolling for hours and hours. It's in Twitter's best interest to rope you in. It's that same "special sauce" that means that the majority of your followers don't see your posts unless they explicitly go looking for them. They're there, but they're not in that feed curated by Twitter to make them the most money.

https://mastodon.ar.al/@aral/107501949232455213

Mike Stone boosted
Aral Balkan @aral 2021-12-24 12:39

The difference between a closed, algorithmically-curated silo like Twitter and the fediverse.

Same post.

Twitter: ~43K â€œfollowersâ€, 8 boosts, 58 likes
Fediverse: ~8.43K followers, 57 boosts, 106 likes

Your thousands of â€œfollowersâ€ on Twitter mean nothing because the algorithm (i.e., Twitter, Inc.) decides who gets to hear you.

#fediverse

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-25 04:34

@pyre35 No worries. I didn't take it personally. There's a whole lot of "stupid" in that IoT space that legitimately deserves ridicule. I haven't really openly talked about my motivations much when it comes to "smart assistants", so there's no way I could have expected you to know about it.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-24 21:35

@pyre35 Too often that's where VUI solutions get bogged down. There are some really legitimate uses for VUIs though, and having one that's functional, capable, and respects the privacy of the people that are using it is still a ways out. Mycroft has great potential, but I'm worried that they're getting hamstrung by poor management decisions, which could push development of a viable solution outside of Google and Amazon back years if they can't get their crap worked out. 6/6

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-24 21:30

@pyre35 that wasn't spying on me and my mother and trying to monetize every word. Solutions like Mycroft have a great deal of potential, but they don't have the financial backing Google Assistant and Alexa have. Mycroft is really the Linux of the VUI market. Unfortunately it's even harder to get people to seriously look at it. There's a lot of trivial garbage that comes along with the IoT market that muddies the waters. No one needs to turn on their toaster from another state. 5/

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-24 21:27

@pyre35 It definitely concerned me, even at the time, having discussions about medical issues with the nurses with both a Google and an Echo device sitting there listening the whole time. There's real concern with HIPAA compliance and "smart assistants". Privacy isn't something you can expect from either Google or Amazon, so having discussions about subjects that need to be private was a complicated thing. It would have been nice to have something that could have filled those requirements 4/

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-24 21:25

@pyre35 I ended up getting her one of the big Google screens because it had the "smart" follow feature, so she'd stay in my field of view even if she started walking away. That worked for a while until she stopped recognizing me. It was also pseudo-nice in that I could use it as a digital picture frame so she could see pictures of my brother's and my families. I was hoping it would help her remember things a little bit. Don't think it had much impact in the long run though. 3/

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-24 21:23

@pyre35 The nurses brought it in and plugged it in for her, but even then it often ended up getting unplugged for some reason or another. I could use the "Drop In" feature (which just lets you connect a "call" without intervention on their side), but she would just forget that she was talking to someone and just walk away in the middle of the conversation. I needed to get her something with video so she would have a visual reminder that she was talking to someone. 2/

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-24 21:21

@pyre35 Yea, when Mom was getting towards the end, she had to go into a care facility. Adding to the complexity of the situation was the fact that Covid hit while she was there. They locked the place down, so I couldn't get in to see her. She couldn't operate even the simplest cell phones by that time, and calling the nurses station usually just ended up with endless ringing and no answers. I ended up getting her an Echo and configuring it for her in my car sitting in the parking lot. 1/

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-24 05:37

@Coneng #Mycroft integrates with Home Assistant, which already has significant integrations with devices throughout the IoT market.

https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-24 03:32

@pyre35 Amazon and Google by the time the technology actually arrives for people to communicate with their computers just like they do with other people. 3/3

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-24 03:32

@pyre35 After a while it got to a point where she couldn't remember how to answer a phone, or use a remote on a TV. It was pretty obvious that the only thing that was so ingrained in her mind that she wouldn't forget it was speech. In fairness, she eventually lost that too, but not until last. Having a VUI to technology would have let her be self sufficient for longer than she was able. Unfortunately, the technology just wasn't there in time for her. I don't want it to be owned by 2/

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-24 03:29

@pyre35 Understood. It's really not for everybody. I always find the whole IoT designation annoying. The voice "assistant" is really just another iteration of a UI. We went from CLI to GUI. Voice assistants are just VUIs. I wanted a smart VUI because my parents were never good with technology, and after my dad passed and my mom started having issues with her Alzheimer's, it got to the point where she couldn't use even the most basic tech. 1/

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-24 02:41

I don't remember when it was actually delivered, but well before I backed the Mark 2 in February of 2018. I'd guess it's at least 4 years old. The Mark 2 will probably still be FUNCTIONAL and useful in 4 years, but it will be FAR from state of the art.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-24 00:22

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-23 23:58

@hejowhat Oh, and I wasn't even factoring in the fact that the very first production round won't be shipped until September of 2022, so even if you buy at full price from their store right now, you're not going to get that until for almost 9 months. That's when that 10% value starts to kick in, so it's close to 4 years from September of 2022, which would be middle of 2026, which considering the Kickstarter was 2017/2018, that's a pretty long ass wait.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-23 23:54

@hejowhat Yea, unfortunately. Mycroft has elected to put their backers behind sales from their store in their list of priorities. I'm guessing there's a financial reason for this. I expect that after 4 years of not producing their product, they can't afford to fill the backers orders. So, after waiting 4 years for delivery, there's a potential 4 more years before that product gets delivered. If it gets delivered. With those numbers, that feels like a pretty big if.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-23 23:47

@hejowhat Unfortunately according to what Michael said, I think you are. The 500 units is the minimum expected production run. Assuming they're correct on that, 10% of that would go to backers, which would be 50 per month, or a meager 600 units per year.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-23 23:40

Today on the #Mycroft Mattermost Mark 2 chat, Mycroft CEO Michael Lewis posted this:

"A percentage of every production run will go to fulfill Rewards and Perks. The % will vary depending on the rate of production, but the minimum expectation is 500 units total per month, and at least 10% of that will be rewards and perks. It's not what we'd prefer, but it's what we can realistically do."

There are 2245 backers on Kickstarter. That means it may take as long as 4 more years for some people.

@splatt9990 It was a CRT, but I doubt luck had much to do with it. These monitors were from the early 90s, maybe even the late 80s. Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-23 00:07

@screenbeard@aus.social Other than backing their paid products funds the development of their open sourced software? Probably not. In theory, it does put together a device that's in an appliance form factor, and that's not super easy to do on your own for most people. If you're comfortable having something a little less aesthetically pleasing, or you're capable of creating something as aesthetically pleasing yourself, just print it out now. You'll definitely be done before they ship their product.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-23 00:01

@screenbeard@aus.social I think the whole selling point is that they're privacy respecting. That being said, that blurb isn't entirely accurate. Or rather, the way it's written is misleading. The company's backend, Selene, is also open sourced.

https://github.com/MycroftAI/selene-backend

The client connects to the backend, but the backend CAN be hosted on your own local network. Individuals can still use Mycroft's hosted version and still enjoy the enhanced privacy over Google and Amazon, but an account is required.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-22 20:51

The pro version comes with several desktop configurations to choose from to make it easier for new users to jump right in. Nothing that you can't do yourself if you want to spend the time, but it's nice and convenient to have it done for you "out of the box". It also preinstalls a whole bunch of stuff for you to save you time.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-22 06:50

@adamsdesk@mastodon.technology While I understand the logic in choosing the Google or the Amazon device considering the price point, it's annoying because that Mycroft unit can literally have a keyboard, mouse, and monitor plugged into it and used as a fairly respectable computer complete with GUI, web browser, word processor, etc. You're not going to be doing FPS games on the thing or anything, but it would be perfectly usable for the majority of tasks a person who doesn't use a computer professionally would do.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-22 06:43

@adamsdesk@mastodon.technology Yea, I agree. The problem is that most people aren't going to be comparing the price to the raw materials. They're going to be comparing it to the $20 they can get a low end Echo for, or the $25 for the low end Google speaker. The question then becomes is the privacy aspect of the #Mycroft worth over $270? I fear that the majority of people are going to say no. This is yet another place the whole "big tech" advantage comes into play. Amazon and Google can sell at a loss.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-15 15:32

An interesting article this morning from goldyfruit on how to deploy Mycroft virtual assistants using #Ansible. For those unfamiliar with #Mycroft (which I talk about constantly), it's an open source virtual assistant that can (when paired with 3rd party solutions like Home Assistant) can control your smart home by voice similarly to the #Amazon Echo or the #Google Assistant. Just with less spying. In fact, the whole stack can be run locally.

https://opensource.com/article/21/12/mycroft-raspberry-pi-ansible

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-06 15:35

@Iutech It depends a great deal upon the context in my personal opinion. What was the question being asked? Linus isn't exactly a typical "newb". He has a YouTube channel with over 14 million subscribers. Also, the fact that the developer responded to questions SHOULD be a benefit. As I said, how many times has a Windows developer reached out and answered questions? So, IS it extremely damaging, or is Linus expecting something from a Linux developer he'd never expect otherwise?

@Linux4Everyone

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-03 16:37

@wswartzendruber I've had that happen more times than I care to mention. One client sent us a private key to access their SFTP server. We tried to send them our public key, and they said their SOP was they generated new public/private keypairs for all their clients, kept the public keys and sent the new private keys to the clients. We had to custom our automation software to use that private key just for them. Caused all sorts of headaches.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-03 01:59

Mike Stone @mike 2021-12-02 23:36

I sometimes feel like I fail communicating with non-technical people because terminology can be confusing for people who don't specialize in IT. Today, I literally spent over 30 minutes going back and forth with a project manager trying to explain to them that WE need a client's public PGP key to encrypt a file, and THEY need our public SSH keys to allow us to authenticate to their SFTP server to send those files. Confused by the clients instructions on how to install PuTTY and generate a key.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-25 02:38

@davidskg10 Plug and play is a great feature, but Windows and macOS have it too. It works on pretty much every major OS out there these days. Peer pressure could certainly be a factor, but you need to have a large enough group to apply that pressure. It's getting to that tipping point that's the real trick.

@mart @danrabbit@mastodon.social

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-25 02:36

@pyre35 Heh, I honestly don't think a clean, friendly UI is going to be enough. Today's Linux desktops are more than capable. People have certainly used worse versions of Windows. #Zorin is a great example, as is #Elementary. They're great distros. Clean. Friendly. Beautiful UIs. But Windows and macOS are fine. Linux UIs don't offer anything unique enough to draw people in. They can do the work to install #Linux and then use it, or just use whatever came on their computer.

@jb @danrabbit@mastodon.social

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-25 01:30

@pyre35 I couldn't begin to tell you how many people I've talked to about it, but I've been using it almost 25 years. I've installed it for people on their computers, and some even stuck with it. Right up until they replaced their computer with a new one, and they didn't care enough about the OS of the computer to want Linux back. Windows or macOS is "good enough" so they don't need to go through the effort of installing Linux. That's pretty much where it falls down every time.

@jb @danrabbit@mastodon.social

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-25 01:21

@pyre35 I don't disagree, but I think planting that interest in an AVERAGE person is easier said than done. A specific demographic? Sure. I got into Linux because I didn't want to constantly have to dial up to my university's DEC Unix server for my programming classes. For some people it's the "free", regardless of definition. We're still talking about a small minority that's going to be interested in doing it instead of something else. What would attract a more general group?

@jb @danrabbit@mastodon.social

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-24 20:08

@seb Agreed, which is why Linux would have to do something significant to ever be a possibility. It would have to be so significant that it would draw the attention of the general population, which doesn't normally pay attention to those sorts of things, and motivate them to do something they normally wouldn't even consider. Either that, or pay someone else to do it. What would a modern OS require to motivate someone that way?

@danrabbit@mastodon.social

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-24 20:06

@Ged Convergence is really an interesting problem. It's arguable whether convergence is a better solution to just flat out interoperability.

It WOULD be cool to have a wirelessly operating convergence device. A screen, keyboard, and mouse that work on your phone, but don't require a connection other than WiFi. You could start an email in your car while sitting at a stoplight. Get home and without plugging in or anything, just continue where you left off with a full keyboard/mouse.

@danrabbit@mastodon.social

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-24 18:24

@dallin@librem.one Thank you!

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-24 18:22

@PublicNuisance I agree that most people would want that. I still don't see that they would move to Linux from the OS they currently have, even if that's what they got. If it works EXACTLY the same, why move? More privacy? More control? Those are things that people should be interested in, but those same people are using Facebook and Instagram. Privacy isn't a huge motivator, and I honestly don't think they WANT the control.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-24 18:20

@Ged And I get that, those are important factors for me too, and they really SHOULD be important factors for everybody IMHO, but Windows and macOS are "good enough" for the average person in those respects, and they're already on the computer when it gets bought. I legitimately don't know if there's anything an OS can offer in this day and age that would be enough of an advantage to get people to want to move from Windows or macOS.

@danrabbit@mastodon.social

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-24 18:16

@jb I agree that privacy and control are huge factors for me, but they're not enough for the average person to dump Windows or macOS to move to the Linux desktop. They probably should be, but aren't. I just wonder what it would be that would finally tip the average person over the edge. It's not going to be privacy. It's not going to be control. It's not going to be a flashy UI. Windows and macOS are "good enough" in those respects, and they're already there.

@danrabbit@mastodon.social

It's more than capable, but at this point is it even possible as a desktop OS to provide that extra bit that would get average people to switch? What is it people actually NEED from a desktop OS?

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-23 15:31

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-23 06:21

@funkwhale Sometimes it's a cut and dry situation, and sometimes it's not. When we see an instance like nazi.social (a real instance btw), it's not a hard decision to block it. Instances like shitposter.club are more ambiguous. Yes, there is some highly objectionable material. There is also some material that our community may find value in. Our decision so far as has been to block problematic users at an instance level, which keeps those users from interacting with any member of our instance.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-23 03:15

@kev Oh yea, those are some cute puppies. My kids would trade me in a second for one of those.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-23 03:12

@mallardbeakman It can be a really good way to make sure your ideas are heard. You just need to make sure you're on an appropriate instance. There are instances that are considered "general" instances where the subject matter can be virtually anything, and there are more specific communities like Fosstodon, where we prefer the majority of the subject matter to be FOSS related. We know people have other interests, but subjects like religion or politics are only tolerated in small amounts.

@uoya

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-23 01:28

@mallardbeakman Literally thousands of others.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-23 01:22

@mallardbeakman Well, Mastodon works a little differently than #Twitter in that there's an instance timeline and a federated timeline in addition to your Home timeline. Home is basically like Twitter. The local timeline is everybody on your instance (#Fosstodon in this case), and the federated timeline is everybody on instances your instance communicates with. While I don't know anything about your former Twitter account, it's likely more people can see what you post here than there.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-23 01:17

@mallardbeakman Nope. I still have more than one Twitter account (unused at the moment), and I've never been "censored" on any of them. I doubt I ever will be at this point since I never login to anything other than Mastodon these days.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-22 21:03

@StrawberryShortcake Anything we block, mute, or limit in any way at an instance level is automatically visible on the About/More page:

https://fosstodon.org/about/more

If it's not listed there, we don't have any policy regarding it at the instance level. Individuals may block that instance, but Fosstodon itself.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-22 17:57

@fedops I don't disagree, especially since Jim annoyed the hell out of me the second he signed on, but this makes elitism purely a matter of perception. If I found Jim intelligent and thoughtful with an insightful and cheerful take on technology, I may feel the same way about Jim you feel regarding FÃ©lim and Joe. It's my opinion that if we're going to be calling out elitism within the community, we need to call out what's being said, not just how likable the person saying it is.

@kev @tomdeb

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-22 17:19

@zigpress@mastodon.technology Sorry to hear that was your experience.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-22 17:17

@kev @tomdeb Honestly, the community I've experienced the MOST elitism from has been the Apple community. Just reading the comments section on an Apple specific site gives me the urge to vomit.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-22 16:30

@funkwhale The question has come up many times actually, and I expect it will continue to. That particular instance (along with several others) has been particularly problematic. So far, we've come down on the side of dealing with issues on a user by user basis. We do HIGHLY encourage people to report individuals engaging in the behavior you mentioned. It may be that an instance ban is the appropriate action.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-22 07:28

@RyuKurisu You can.

@funkwhale@mastodon.eliotberriot.com @funkwhale

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-22 07:26

@mcread There are some instances that #Fosstodon blocks as an instance. Those decisions are not made by individuals. Our moderation team decides them as a group. You can rest assured, if an instance gets blocked, it's not for no reason. It may be for a reason you don't personally agree with, but a reason none the less. Our team is available for questions if you have them.

@funkwhale

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-22 07:17

@thatbrickster Well, I can say unequivocally that we don't currently block traffic from your instance. Individuals might, but not the instance as a whole. All the instances blocked by #Fosstodon can be seen on the About/More page. Of course, your free to ask if you've got any questions.

@funkwhale

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-20 22:32

My daughter and her classmate were trying to figure out who was "smarter" by trying to stump each other with basic division, which they just started learning in school.

D: What's 1/1?
F: 1! What's 2/1?
D: 2! What's 10/1?
F: That's easy! 10!
Me walking by: What's 1/0?
D: 1!
Me: Nope.
F: 0!
Me: Nope.

It's been 25 minutes now, and they're still whispering back and forth to themselves trying to figure it out. ðŸ˜†

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-18 20:31

@monkey1 I think it would be great for customers if Apple is serious about this, but I have very little faith that they are committed. Honestly, I think it's just a bunch of hand waving to hold off regulators. If anything useful actually comes of this, I'll be shocked.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-18 15:54

@kev Depends. Apple is probably still going to jump to "replacement" before "repair" as it exposes them to less liability. When Apple wants "replace" and the individual wants "repair", there's potential for overlap. This happened to me and my wife when we owned iPhones. My wife's phone just turned off and never turned back on. We took it to the "Genius" bar, and they replaced the phone, but we lost weeks of pictures of our infant son. "Repair" wasn't an option, but I would have preferred it.

I'm assuming it's null and void after a self repair.

@chamilad I doubt that it would be too much for git. Depending on where you're using git, it'll support massive repos. Speaking personally, I don't store most of my files in my home directory. Mike Stone @mike 2021-11-07 04:05

What is the big malfunction here? Why so long?

Me: We've been experiencing intermittent issues from one of your services.

Tech: OK, we restarted the service. Is it working now?

Tech: OK.

5 minutes later....

Tech: Is it fixed?

Me: Well, it's working, but it's only been five minutes so we don't know if it's fixed.

Tech: OK.

5 minutes later.....

Tech: Is this issue resolved?

Me: ......

Flavors to eat
Vanilla and chocolate and mint

I'm hungry and hot

Eugen Rochko @Gargron 2021-10-28 22:16

A small victory: An hour after we sent a cease & desist letter to #Gab's legal team on Oct 21 regarding their failure to publish up-to-date source code in compliance with Mastodon's AGPLv3 license, they have uploaded a new version.

That is not all that we demanded in the letter, but it is nevertheless a victory in upholding the AGPLv3 license of our project, and a signal to those who doubt that we are willing to show teeth to those who ignore it.

More context: https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/07/statement-on-gabs-fork-of-mastodon/

@bignose A non-Facebook Metaverse is actually a cool idea. I'd be onboard with it. I'd like to see the metaverse where communication protocols and hardware standards are established and universal so any vendor can create compatible hardware. Software would be open source and federated so anybody could host their own zone, which could be as small as a room or house and as big as a planet or even solar system. Of course, that wouldn't let #Mehta control the whole thing, so probably won't happen.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-28 16:19

@mplammers Yea, you're probably right. Trolling and lack of clarity. Trolling is one of the reasons we don't want to debate moderation activity in the public timeline.

I'll talk to Kev and the mod team and see if we can add some clarity to that Spam rule. Hopefully that will prevent exchanges like this in the future.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-28 16:15

@xpil Ooo, yea. I remember walking over a mile in sub-0F to eject a floppy from a drive after I repeatedly asked if one was there and was assured not. Then I walked back.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-28 16:05

@picamanic No clue why that happened, but I can verify that your account is fine. I just looked at it and there are no limitations imposed or any warnings or restrictions. As far as #Fosstodon is concerned, you're all good.

@Iutech

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-28 15:35

@MaciejFicek There's not a fixed number. It depends on the content of your post. If you post 4 words and 12 hashtags, that's spam. There should never be more hashtags than there are words in your post. Ideally the majority of your hashtags should be actual words you've used in the content of you post. Adding one or two to the end isn't going to set off any alarms. The point of the exercise is that the content of your post should be content meant to be read by humans.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-28 15:30

@MaciejFicek The "icon" is on my profile page. It's the Red text that says "Admin". People from the Moderation team will have green text that says "Mod".

Promoting a product is fine. It shouldn't be all you post, and you should be giving us a reason why it's being promoted. We shouldn't have to click through on a link to know why that link is relevant. That means if we can't tell why we should be clicking on a link, your post is probably spam.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-28 15:14

@MaciejFicek Your posts weren't previously flagged because there's close to 20000 people on Fosstodon, and our moderation team doesn't read each and every post from each and every individual. When one of your posts were brought to our attention, a warning was sent.

Another part of our Code of Conduct is "do not debate moderation actions in public toots", which is what you're doing right now. You're welcome to email me or another team member, but take this out of the public timeline.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-28 15:10

@MaciejFicek The bot you're referring to is not on Fosstodon, and it's "spamming" is not posted on our local timeline. The rules for posts on our local timeline are different than the rules of other accounts on other instances.

What's wrong with a post with twelve hashtags is it's spammy, and we don't want it on our local timeline. That's in our Code of Conduct. We don't want to have to click through to a page to know what is being talked about.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-27 20:11

@cassidyjames I saw your post and was like, "No fair! Mine hasn't shi..."

Ding! New notification from the Google Store.....

Says mine will be here on the 2nd or 3rd. Anxiously waiting. If they can get it here sooner that would be even better.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-27 20:03

@MaciejFicek The issue isn't with cryptocurrencies. This isn't Twitter. When you say, "Please watch this very important video", with a link and a barrage of hashtags, that's basically spam. What is that video about? Why is it "important"? You've provided the community with no useful information. A post with 4 words, a link, and 12 hashtags is spam. A video just a single hashtag and no explanation is spam. If you have questions about our policies, you can always DM anybody on the team.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-27 19:23

There are actually a few distros in this article that I'm not familiar with. I love trying out different distros as I honestly feel that an active and diverse distro "market" helps Linux evolve over time into something better than it would be otherwise.

https://www.techspot.com/article/2334-linux-distros/

I'm still thinking of supporting, because I like the idea. I have serious concerns though.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-21 19:44

I don't want this to be a political post. This is just a testament to the strength of the Fediverse. New instances can join, drop, or any combination of the two, and it doesn't impact the Fed at large. Being a distributed social network means that one node of that network can experience catastrophic failure and it will have no impact on the rest of the network.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-21 19:21

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-20 16:35

@ivanrancic It might be easier to do the installation from GitHub. That's where I've always done mine from.

git clone https://github.com/MycroftAI/mycroft-core.git
cd mycroft-core
bash ./dev_setup.sh

This will ask some really straight forward questions (I pretty much just answer Y to all of them). It'll do a bunch of stuff. When it's done:

./start-mycroft.sh all
./bin/mycroft-cli-client

You can watch the logs and stuff from the cli client, and you should be in business at this point.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-20 16:31

@cassidyjames I was a little concerned about the size too, but I really liked my Pixel 2 XL, and the Pixel 6 Pro is not significantly bigger. I have an order in for a Pixel 6 Pro, and I'm super anxious to get it.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-20 15:56

@brandon Which only makes sense. If they have a remotely decent scheduler, they're going to see better multi-core performance when they add more cores. To a point anyway. Apple can't just keep adding more and more cores. Eventually the return is going to flatline. The interesting thing is going to be when Apple does something more than add more cores, more GPUs and more RAM to the SoC.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-18 21:03

@mcol The biggest caveat I can see right now is that things aren't super speedy on the standard #PinePhone. Thankfully @PINE64 has recently given us the solution to that problem with the #PinePhonePro. I'm really looking forward to seeing how things perform with a little bit more under the hood.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-18 21:02

@mcol Well, Mycroft isn't "designed" to work in a mobile environment, it just happens that the Plasma Mobile running on Manjaro is basically the same as a desktop version as far as Mycroft is concerned. Anything you can do on a computer or an appliance with Mycroft you can do on a PinePhone. Mycroft works with Home Assistant to allow for voice control of virtually anything Home Assistant works with. Top that off with the whole stack being open source and it's hard to go wrong.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-18 20:53

@mcol Speaking for myself, I hate virtually all tasks that require me to type on a phone. Plus, quick tasks like just asking for the weather. Add to that automation tasks like dealing with lights and appliances are all possible from virtually anywhere if you configure the device correctly. All of that while keeping your privacy intact.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-18 20:47

@person That very well could be true, but having the faster hardware won't hurt even after the optimizations are improved.

Ders :ubuntu: :debian: :arch: @MrDers 2021-10-14 15:42

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-14 15:54

@MrDers Heh, I have a blog, and I even update it occasionally, but I'm under no illusions that there are people in the world that would actually PAY me to have the pleasure to read what I occasionally spew out. I don't want to annoy the few people who visit my little corner of the Internet by placing ads, so those random individuals get whatever it is that pops out of my brain free from trackers, advertising, and monetization.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-10-14 14:58

@danjones000

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-23 18:06

@Tay0 Where I work, we have three environments. A development server, at test server, and our production servers.

Our development server is what's used by our developers to actually develop stuff, which for ME makes it production.

Our test server is what's used by our QA/QE teams to test stuff, which for ME makes it production.

Our production servers are used to host our production stuff, which for me makes it production.

Nowhere in there am I allowed to try new things.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-23 18:00

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-23 17:57

Uh, no. They pay me the least amount required to keep me from walking out the door. If I work my ass off 24/7, they'll still pay me the least they can get away with. I guess that's just as much on me, since if I am willing to accept a low number, they're willing to pay me a low number.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-23 17:51

"Senior leadership makes me optimistic for the future of this organization"

Do I disagree if I think the company is doing fine even if senior leadership is doing little to nothing to make it that way?

Do I agree if I think the company is going to be fine because of it's market position even if it seriously screws up due to poor decisions by senior management?

I'm not saying senior management is bad or that they're screwing things up, but the question??

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-23 16:49

@danjones000 I use WSL, but it's probably overkill for my needs. I spend very little time on the actual local system other than email and stuff like that, so WSL turns into a glorified terminal app for me. The vast majority of the time I have it open it's being used to ssh into a remote system. Recent versions have allowed for GUI apps, but I've never gone that far. Theoretically it would allow me to run Linux versions of my software, which MIGHT have a security advantage. Dunno.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-23 16:28

Don't get me wrong here. I love #Mycroft, but the Mark II is a Raspberry Pi with a custom daughter board in a custom case. It's what most people on HackADay do on their weekends. Q2 of 2022 makes it almost four years late. ðŸ˜

Jacie? ðŸ¦ðŸ¦ðŸ¦ðŸ¦ @jacethechicken 2021-09-21 17:23

psa: your co-workers who have been there for longer and don't work as fast as you aren't ""lazy,"" they're exhausted. they were in your position once too, and felt like they had to put in all their energy ito the job -- and they burnt out. you should learn from them, and slow down now. take rest breaks and coffee breaks, let things take a little longer; your reward for extra speed will only ever be more assignments, inevitably grinding you down. your exploitative employer isn't worth it.

Mike Stone boosted
Will Cooke @8none1 2021-09-14 10:26

Home Assistant is strange. You can't install it "normally" on a Pi because Python is too old (it wants 3.8, Raspbian has 3.7). You can install it via Docker but then you can't use Add-Ons. If you want full functionality you're really left with one choice - install their entire OS image on a dedicated Pi. For a collection of Python scripts.

Mike Stone boosted
Ru @celia 2021-09-14 13:03

@obsolete29 Shameless plug:

https://rusingh.com/2020/06/28/secure-cloud-vps/

The Fosstodon post has tons of good advice too: https://fosstodon.org/@celia/104421621463347177

@uoya

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-14 15:49

Some days are good days, some days you get threatened and called a motherf*cker a bunch before you even get out of bed.

Today is a motherf*cker day.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-14 15:44

@fedops By default, they do use cloud services for processing. There's just too much stuff for a Pi to handle on its own. They also have an open source version of their backend, so you can install it on prem and not use their cloud services. That requires a lot more than a Pi to run, and I've never tried it myself, but theoretically you can run it on your Intranet without outside connectivity.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-14 02:11

@jonasvautherin So far I've been happy, but my expectations weren't that high. You're DEFINITELY not going to want to use it for recording of any kind. The audio quality just isn't good enough with the integrated microphone. It seems to work perfectly fine to run an assistant off of though. There's a little bit of a hiss on the integrated speakers, but you really have listen for it. The audio output on the integrated speakers isn't great, and I haven't tried pulling in external speakers yet.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-14 00:12

Day 30 of the #100DaysToOffload 2021 Series:

Yea, I got tired of waiting....

https://mikestone.me/cheap-and-easy-picroft/

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-13 16:44

@Gina Now I'm hungry.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-12 19:44

@pheonix I used to have one at my that I really liked. It was electronically adjustable, and so I would stand at it for a while, and then sit for a while. I wouldn't recommend trying to stand ALL day, especially right off the bat. I did really like having the option though, and I did use it regularly. Unfortunately, I haven't been into the office now for a year and a half, and I've been missing it. I've been thinking about getting one for home.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-12 19:35

@bob @Hamishcampbell @tychosoft @aral The expense could be covered by donations, but that's hard to ask for up front rather than after you've gotten a successful site, and @kev and I aren't secret billionaires. I suppose if we were we could hire a bunch of people to watch all the videos and make sure they're not pirated content, opening us up to massive liability issues. Since we're not, and we both have jobs and families and lives that don't involve a keyboard (occasionally), we don't do video.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-12 19:32

@bob @Hamishcampbell @tychosoft @aral Yea, it's not a simple problem. I considered creating a PeerTube instance for #Fosstodon at one point but quickly realized it would not be a small undertaking. If you want it to be anything other than a raging cesspool of garbage there needs to be active moderation of content, which takes some real time and effort when it comes to video. Then, there's the expense of it all. An active site with more than a couple users would require expensive infrastructure.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-05 09:03

@simon I use it for the #Mycroft voice output. MycroftAI has made some pretty good advancements in the last 5ish years that I've been supporting them, but their voices are pretty sad. They have the original AP voice, which I still use on my Mark I, they have a "newer" American voice, and the Google Voice is an option. Even the Google voice isn't actually from their assistant, it's what reads out from their translation site. AWS Polly has been the easiest alternative to get running.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-03 20:42

@wholesomedonut @sbanwart The problem we've run into specifically (and I don't think my particular company is alone in this) is that when "new" things are brought online, we try to use them as much like the old stuff as possible. When we brought Jira into our workflow, they tried to configure it to be as much like what was there before as they could instead of looking at Jira and seeing what it's good and bad at. In doing so, we've ended up with a mediocre product doing things the worst way.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-02 16:22

@LinuxLegend @Nongchiddler @wizzwizz4 Well, there's already clients that do it. Last I looked I believe FediLab on Android had the option. You can search for the domain name and you'll get a brief list of accounts and posts (this isn't a great option though). The other thing is you can go to the domain and view the public timeline there. Usually it's just /public on the domain, like this:

https://mastodon.technology/public

You can see content there and follow click on accounts to follow.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-09-02 15:49

@Brynjar Welcome! I'd assume since you joined #Fosstodon that you have an interest in FOSS, so the local timeline is going to be a great place to start. Those are posts that are made only by the people on this instance. Another place to look around would be the Trunk. It's a page with individuals broken down by interest.

https://communitywiki.org/trunk

The next thing is just searching for hash tags. Hashes can be pinned to the advanced interface, so it's a great way to find posts.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-28 00:44

I suppose I shouldn't be surprised that my usage this year is lower than the same time last year. The kids aren't home all day this year. What did surprise me is when comparing like usage from last year, it looks like they're actually charging me LESS. I was not expecting that.

Lars Wirzenius @liw 2021-08-26 08:21

It's that time of the year again.

I've been using Linux for about 30 years. Mine was the first installation, given Linus didn't install it on his computer, he grew it on top of an existing Minix install, replacing it piecemeal.

My first contribution is over 30 years ago, about April, 1991, the sprintf (now snprintf) function in the kernel.

It's been a fun ride.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-26 21:07

@felimwhiteley One thing that I find useful when I'm super busy is I "follow" particular people just through my RSS reader so I don't miss their comments. Every individual has an RSS feed you can view just by adding .rss to their profile. For example, mine is here:

https://fosstodon.org/@mike.rss

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-26 20:50

@fedops Honestly, a couple years back we used to do notifications through Slack. It was actually better in my mind. It worked almost like a log file. I just turned off notifications on "channels" that weren't super important and I could get many notifications all at the same time without them intermingling and turning into a big mess of garbage. @kamme @hund

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-26 18:42

@fedops During the day, I have no idea how many emails I'd get if I had filtering off. I shudder to think. I've always got Outlook open and filtering, so I don't have to know I guess. It's definitely more than 30. I just checked ONE of the folders I filter into (there are 20+ folders catch filtered stuff), and there was 46 in there since 8:00 this morning. I've never bothered to count, but I don't think the folder I checked is the one that gets the most messages.

@kamme @hund

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-26 18:23

@kamme @hund Not that I know of, other than filter as much as possible and deal with the rest. Honestly, I mostly ignore my email because it's so damn useless. If people need my attention, I'm available on Teams. If they send me an email, they're probably not going to get a response.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-26 18:02

@hund @kamme To make matters worse, I don't even know what some of this crap is. I got some this morning titled "**** **** Files Transferred", and all that was in the body of the message was a file name. I don't know what that file is or where it was transferred from or to. No one has mentioned it to me and I didn't ask to be notified of its delivery. I have NO idea why I get that message. I get them daily, multiple times a day.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-26 17:59

@hund @kamme Most of it isn't from "people". My company seems to be under the deluded impression that email is the best way to notify people of pretty much anything. Unusual system message in a log? Email. Assigned a new ticket? Email. Process delayed? Email. Email. Email. That's why almost all of it gets filtered automatically. It's useless noise. There's more useless noise that isn't caught by my filters because it's close enough to not noise I don't want to take the chance. Still mostly crap.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-26 17:21

I got over 800 emails between signing out last night (end of day ~ 5:00 in the evening), and signing in this morning (start of day ~ 8:00 in the morning). Filters cut that down to a little bit more than 60, and after visual inspection of the rest, I read precisely 2 of them.

Yea, email works GREAT. ðŸ˜’

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-16 21:36

@kev Soooooo... what you're saying is my idea to move #Fosstodon to a Pi4 is a bad one?

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-16 21:15

@RyuKurisu Sure. Here's a script:

#!/usr/bin/sh

echo This is a script.
echo $SUDO_USER ran it.

If you run this as yourself, the output is:

This is a script
ran it.

If you run it with sudo, the output is:

This is a script
<username> ran it.

Where <username> is the account name you ran the script from. So, if my username is mike, it would say "mike ran it".

This really helps out with things like logging.

@twann

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-16 19:50

How is it that I've been writing shell scripts for over 15 years now to automate processes, and I've only just discovered $SUDO_USER today? I feel like that's a MASSIVE oversight.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-16 18:50

@Tay0 I agree. I love #Mycroft, but they've been flailing about the last couple years trying to do what Pine64 does on a regular basis. @PINE64 stepping in with a hardware option would be a huge boon to the community and put focus back on a product that I think has not gotten the attention it deserves. Plus, I think Pine64 could sell some hardware.

@pixelherodev

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-16 17:45

@pixelherodev Isn't the same true of #Mycroft? Mycroft is there, and exists in the real world. It's biggest problem is that it's smart speaker software without a smart speaker to run on. #MycroftAI has been working on getting their hardware released for over 4 years now. In that time, Mycroft has only run on the aging Mark I devices, cobbled together Picrofts, and PCs which it's not designed to run on efficiently. An NPU may be helpful, but Mycroft's own hardware is simply a Pi 4.

@PINE64

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-16 17:34

@pixelherodev Well, that's kinda the thing with @PINE64. They provide the hardware. The community provides the software. The same is true with the #Pinephone, #Pinetab, and #Pinetime. Even the #PinebookPro.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-16 04:31

@hund Loads of things. They interface with smart stuff in your house, like thermostats and lights so you can control those with a voice command. General stuff like asking stupid questions, like what time it is or how the weather is, or how many kilometers makes up a mile, or what time is it in another location. Of course Mycroft is open source, so anything you can code you can do. The major trick is being able to ask it questions in plain language, and get answers back.

@PINE64

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-16 04:18

@hund Generic term for a device like the Amazon Echo or the Google Assistant devices. The Mycroft Mark I is a smart speaker.

@PINE64

It doesn't do much else at this point, but more is incoming, and it respects my privacy while still giving me more data than a cheap Casio. Soooo, is it useful? It is for me. Depends on what you're looking for.

Make sure to check it out and, if you haven't already done so, make your first toot and tell us a bit about yourself.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-08-02 15:30

@murph Yea, when an instance gets blocked it take all individuals from that instance and removes all references to them. It has impact even if the block is removed. The only reason I went ahead with the block is because the instance was single user and the size of the impact.
